4507         return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
4508 
4509     def _entropy(self):
4510         return np.log(2*np.pi)
4511 
4512     @_call_super_mom
4513     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
4514     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
4515         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
4516             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
4517 
4518         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
4519                                                          args, kwds)
4520 
4521         # location is independent from the scale
4522         data_min = np.min(data)
4523         if floc is not None:
4524             if data_min < floc:
4525                 # There are values that are less than the specified loc.
4526                 raise FitDataError("halfcauchy", lower=floc, upper=np.inf)
4527             loc = floc
4528         else:
4529             # if not provided, location MLE is the minimal data point
4530             loc = data_min
4531 
4532         # find scale
4533         def find_scale(loc, data):
4534             shifted_data = data - loc
4535             n = data.size
4536             shifted_data_squared = np.square(shifted_data)
4537 
4538             def fun_to_solve(scale):
4539                 denominator = scale**2 + shifted_data_squared
4540                 return 2 * np.sum(shifted_data_squared/denominator) - n
4541 
4542             small = np.finfo(1.0).tiny**0.5  # avoid underflow
4543             res = root_scalar(fun_to_solve, bracket=(small, np.max(shifted_data)))
4544             return res.root
4545 
4546         if fscale is not None:
4547             scale = fscale
4548         else:
4549             scale = find_scale(loc, data)
4550 
4551         return loc, scale
4552 
4553 
4554 halfcauchy = halfcauchy_gen(a=0.0, name='halfcauchy')
4555 
4556 
4557 class halflogistic_gen(rv_continuous):
4558     r"""A half-logistic continuous random variable. 
4559  
4560     %(before_notes)s 
4561  
4562     Notes 
4563     ----- 
4564     The probability density function for `halflogistic` is: 
4565  
4566     .. math:: 
4567  
4568         f(x) = \frac{ 2 e^{-x} }{ (1+e^{-x})^2 } 
4569              = \frac{1}{2} \text{sech}(x/2)^2 
4570  
4571     for :math:`x \ge 0`. 
4572  
4573     %(after_notes)s 
4574  
4575     References 
4576     ---------- 
4577     .. [1] Asgharzadeh et al (2011). "Comparisons of Methods of Estimation for the 
4578            Half-Logistic Distribution". Selcuk J. Appl. Math. 93-108. 
4579  
4580     %(example)s 
4581  
4582     """
4583     def _shape_info(self):
4584         return []
4585 
4586     def _pdf(self, x):
4587         # halflogistic.pdf(x) = 2 * exp(-x) / (1+exp(-x))**2
4588         #                     = 1/2 * sech(x/2)**2
4589         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x))
4590 
4591     def _logpdf(self, x):
4592         return np.log(2) - x - 2. * sc.log1p(np.exp(-x))
4593 
4594     def _cdf(self, x):
4595         return np.tanh(x/2.0)
4596 
4597     def _ppf(self, q):
4598         return 2*np.arctanh(q)
4599 
4600     def _sf(self, x):
4601         return 2 * sc.expit(-x)
4602 
4603     def _isf(self, q):
4604         return _lazywhere(q < 0.5, (q, ),
4605                           lambda q: -sc.logit(0.5 * q),
4606                           f2=lambda q: 2*np.arctanh(1 - q))
4607 
4608     def _munp(self, n):
4609         if n == 0:
4610             return 1  # otherwise returns NaN
4611         if n == 1:
4612             return 2*np.log(2)
4613         if n == 2:
4614             return np.pi*np.pi/3.0
4615         if n == 3:
4616             return 9*_ZETA3
4617         if n == 4:
4618             return 7*np.pi**4 / 15.0
4619         return 2*(1-pow(2.0, 1-n))*sc.gamma(n+1)*sc.zeta(n, 1)
4620 
4621     def _entropy(self):
4622         return 2-np.log(2)
4623 
4624     @_call_super_mom
4625     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
4626     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
4627         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
4628             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
4629 
4630         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
4631                                                          args, kwds)
4632 
4633         def find_scale(data, loc):
4634             # scale is solution to a fix point problem ([1] 2.6)
4635             # use approximate MLE as starting point ([1] 3.1)
4636             n_observations = data.shape[0]
4637             sorted_data = np.sort(data, axis=0)
4638             p = np.arange(1, n_observations + 1)/(n_observations + 1)
4639             q = 1 - p
4640             pp1 = 1 + p
4641             alpha = p - 0.5 * q * pp1 * np.log(pp1 / q)
4642             beta = 0.5 * q * pp1
4643             sorted_data = sorted_data - loc
4644             B = 2 * np.sum(alpha[1:] * sorted_data[1:])
4645             C = 2 * np.sum(beta[1:] * sorted_data[1:]**2)
4646             # starting guess
4647             scale = ((B + np.sqrt(B**2 + 8 * n_observations * C))
4648                     /(4 * n_observations))
4649 
4650             # relative tolerance of fix point iterator
4651             rtol = 1e-8
4652             relative_residual = 1
4653             shifted_mean = sorted_data.mean()  # y_mean - y_min
4654 
4655             # find fix point by repeated application of eq. (2.6)
4656             # simplify as
4657             # exp(-x) / (1 + exp(-x)) = 1 / (1 + exp(x))
4658             #                         = expit(-x))
4659             while relative_residual > rtol:
4660                 sum_term = sorted_data * sc.expit(-sorted_data/scale)
4661                 scale_new = shifted_mean - 2/n_observations * sum_term.sum()
4662                 relative_residual = abs((scale - scale_new)/scale)
4663                 scale = scale_new
4664             return scale
4665 
4666         # location is independent from the scale
4667         data_min = np.min(data)
4668         if floc is not None:
4669             if data_min < floc:
4670                 # There are values that are less than the specified loc.
4671                 raise FitDataError("halflogistic", lower=floc, upper=np.inf)
4672             loc = floc
4673         else:
4674             # if not provided, location MLE is the minimal data point
4675             loc = data_min
4676 
4677         # scale depends on location
4678         scale = fscale if fscale is not None else find_scale(data, loc)
4679 
4680         return loc, scale
4681 
4682 
4683 halflogistic = halflogistic_gen(a=0.0, name='halflogistic')
4684 
4685 
4686 class halfnorm_gen(rv_continuous):
4687     r"""A half-normal continuous random variable. 
4688  
4689     %(before_notes)s 
4690  
4691     Notes 
4692     ----- 
4693     The probability density function for `halfnorm` is: 
4694  
4695     .. math:: 
4696  
4697         f(x) = \sqrt{2/\pi} \exp(-x^2 / 2) 
4698  
4699     for :math:`x >= 0`. 
4700  
4701     `halfnorm` is a special case of `chi` with ``df=1``. 
4702  
4703     %(after_notes)s 
4704  
4705     %(example)s 
4706  
4707     """
4708     def _shape_info(self):
4709         return []
4710 
4711     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
4712         return abs(random_state.standard_normal(size=size))
4713 
4714     def _pdf(self, x):
4715         # halfnorm.pdf(x) = sqrt(2/pi) * exp(-x**2/2)
4716         return np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi)*np.exp(-x*x/2.0)
4717 
4718     def _logpdf(self, x):
4719         return 0.5 * np.log(2.0/np.pi) - x*x/2.0
4720 
4721     def _cdf(self, x):
4722         return sc.erf(x / np.sqrt(2))
4723 
4724     def _ppf(self, q):
4725         return _norm_ppf((1+q)/2.0)
4726 
4727     def _sf(self, x):
4728         return 2 * _norm_sf(x)
4729 
4730     def _isf(self, p):
4731         return _norm_isf(p/2)
4732 
4733     def _stats(self):
4734         return (np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi),
4735                 1-2.0/np.pi,
4736                 np.sqrt(2)*(4-np.pi)/(np.pi-2)**1.5,
4737                 8*(np.pi-3)/(np.pi-2)**2)
4738 
4739     def _entropy(self):
4740         return 0.5*np.log(np.pi/2.0)+0.5
4741 
4742     @_call_super_mom
4743     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
4744     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
4745         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
4746             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
4747 
4748         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
4749                                                          args, kwds)
4750 
4751         data_min = np.min(data)
4752 
4753         if floc is not None:
4754             if data_min < floc:
4755                 # There are values that are less than the specified loc.
4756                 raise FitDataError("halfnorm", lower=floc, upper=np.inf)
4757             loc = floc
4758         else:
4759             loc = data_min
4760 
4761         if fscale is not None:
4762             scale = fscale
4763         else:
4764             scale = stats.moment(data, order=2, center=loc)**0.5
4765 
4766         return loc, scale
4767 
4768 
4769 halfnorm = halfnorm_gen(a=0.0, name='halfnorm')
4770 
4771 
4772 class hypsecant_gen(rv_continuous):
4773     r"""A hyperbolic secant continuous random variable. 
4774  
4775     %(before_notes)s 
4776  
4777     Notes 
4778     ----- 
4779     The probability density function for `hypsecant` is: 
4780  
4781     .. math:: 
4782  
4783         f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi} \text{sech}(x) 
4784  
4785     for a real number :math:`x`. 
4786  
4787     %(after_notes)s 
4788  
4789     %(example)s 
4790  
4791     """
4792     def _shape_info(self):
4793         return []
4794 
4795     def _pdf(self, x):
4796         # hypsecant.pdf(x) = 1/pi * sech(x)
4797         return 1.0/(np.pi*np.cosh(x))
4798 
4799     def _cdf(self, x):
4800         return 2.0/np.pi*np.arctan(np.exp(x))
4801 
4802     def _ppf(self, q):
4803         return np.log(np.tan(np.pi*q/2.0))
4804 
4805     def _sf(self, x):
4806         return 2.0/np.pi*np.arctan(np.exp(-x))
4807 
4808     def _isf(self, q):
4809         return -np.log(np.tan(np.pi*q/2.0))
4810 
4811     def _stats(self):
4812         return 0, np.pi*np.pi/4, 0, 2
4813 
4814     def _entropy(self):
4815         return np.log(2*np.pi)
4816 
4817 
4818 hypsecant = hypsecant_gen(name='hypsecant')
4819 
4820 
4821 class gausshyper_gen(rv_continuous):
4822     r"""A Gauss hypergeometric continuous random variable. 
4823  
4824     %(before_notes)s 
4825  
4826     Notes 
4827     ----- 
4828     The probability density function for `gausshyper` is: 
4829  
4830     .. math:: 
4831  
4832         f(x, a, b, c, z) = C x^{a-1} (1-x)^{b-1} (1+zx)^{-c} 
4833  
4834     for :math:`0 \le x \le 1`, :math:`a,b > 0`, :math:`c` a real number, 
4835     :math:`z > -1`, and :math:`C = \frac{1}{B(a, b) F[2, 1](c, a; a+b; -z)}`. 
4836     :math:`F[2, 1]` is the Gauss hypergeometric function 
4837     `scipy.special.hyp2f1`. 
4838  
4839     `gausshyper` takes :math:`a`, :math:`b`, :math:`c` and :math:`z` as shape 
4840     parameters. 
4841  
4842     %(after_notes)s 
4843  
4844     References 
4845     ---------- 
4846     .. [1] Armero, C., and M. J. Bayarri. "Prior Assessments for Prediction in 
4847            Queues." *Journal of the Royal Statistical Society*. Series D (The 
4848            Statistician) 43, no. 1 (1994): 139-53. doi:10.2307/2348939 
4849  
4850     %(example)s 
4851  
4852     """
4853 
4854     def _argcheck(self, a, b, c, z):
4855         # z > -1 per gh-10134
4856         return (a > 0) & (b > 0) & (c == c) & (z > -1)
4857 
4858     def _shape_info(self):
4859         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
4860         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
4861         ic = _ShapeInfo("c", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
4862         iz = _ShapeInfo("z", False, (-1, np.inf), (False, False))
4863         return [ia, ib, ic, iz]
4864 
4865     def _pdf(self, x, a, b, c, z):
4866         normalization_constant = sc.beta(a, b) * sc.hyp2f1(c, a, a + b, -z)
4867         return (1./normalization_constant * x**(a - 1.) * (1. - x)**(b - 1.0)
4868                 / (1.0 + z*x)**c)
4869 
4870     def _munp(self, n, a, b, c, z):
4871         fac = sc.beta(n+a, b) / sc.beta(a, b)
4872         num = sc.hyp2f1(c, a+n, a+b+n, -z)
4873         den = sc.hyp2f1(c, a, a+b, -z)
4874         return fac*num / den
4875 
4876 
4877 gausshyper = gausshyper_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='gausshyper')
4878 
4879 
4880 class invgamma_gen(rv_continuous):
4881     r"""An inverted gamma continuous random variable. 
4882  
4883     %(before_notes)s 
4884  
4885     Notes 
4886     ----- 
4887     The probability density function for `invgamma` is: 
4888  
4889     .. math:: 
4890  
4891         f(x, a) = \frac{x^{-a-1}}{\Gamma(a)} \exp(-\frac{1}{x}) 
4892  
4893     for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`a > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function 
4894     (`scipy.special.gamma`). 
4895  
4896     `invgamma` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`. 
4897  
4898     `invgamma` is a special case of `gengamma` with ``c=-1``, and it is a 
4899     different parameterization of the scaled inverse chi-squared distribution. 
4900     Specifically, if the scaled inverse chi-squared distribution is 
4901     parameterized with degrees of freedom :math:`\nu` and scaling parameter 
4902     :math:`\tau^2`, then it can be modeled using `invgamma` with 
4903     ``a=`` :math:`\nu/2` and ``scale=`` :math:`\nu \tau^2/2`. 
4904  
4905     %(after_notes)s 
4906  
4907     %(example)s 
4908  
4909     """
4910     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
4911 
4912     def _shape_info(self):
4913         return [_ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
4914 
4915     def _pdf(self, x, a):
4916         # invgamma.pdf(x, a) = x**(-a-1) / gamma(a) * exp(-1/x)
4917         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a))
4918 
4919     def _logpdf(self, x, a):
4920         return -(a+1) * np.log(x) - sc.gammaln(a) - 1.0/x
4921 
4922     def _cdf(self, x, a):
4923         return sc.gammaincc(a, 1.0 / x)
4924 
4925     def _ppf(self, q, a):
4926         return 1.0 / sc.gammainccinv(a, q)
4927 
4928     def _sf(self, x, a):
4929         return sc.gammainc(a, 1.0 / x)
4930 
4931     def _isf(self, q, a):
4932         return 1.0 / sc.gammaincinv(a, q)
4933 
4934     def _stats(self, a, moments='mvsk'):
4935         m1 = _lazywhere(a > 1, (a,), lambda x: 1. / (x - 1.), np.inf)
4936         m2 = _lazywhere(a > 2, (a,), lambda x: 1. / (x - 1.)**2 / (x - 2.),
4937                         np.inf)
4938 
4939         g1, g2 = None, None
4940         if 's' in moments:
4941             g1 = _lazywhere(
4942                 a > 3, (a,),
4943                 lambda x: 4. * np.sqrt(x - 2.) / (x - 3.), np.nan)
4944         if 'k' in moments:
4945             g2 = _lazywhere(
4946                 a > 4, (a,),
4947                 lambda x: 6. * (5. * x - 11.) / (x - 3.) / (x - 4.), np.nan)
4948         return m1, m2, g1, g2
4949 
4950     def _entropy(self, a):
4951         def regular(a):
4952             h = a - (a + 1.0) * sc.psi(a) + sc.gammaln(a)
4953             return h
4954 
4955         def asymptotic(a):
4956             # gammaln(a) ~ a * ln(a) - a - 0.5 * ln(a) + 0.5 * ln(2 * pi)
4957             # psi(a) ~ ln(a) - 1 / (2 * a)
4958             h = ((1 - 3*np.log(a) + np.log(2) + np.log(np.pi))/2
4959                  + 2/3*a**-1. + a**-2./12 - a**-3./90 - a**-4./120)
4960             return h
4961 
4962         h = _lazywhere(a >= 2e2, (a,), f=asymptotic, f2=regular)
4963         return h
4964 
4965 
4966 invgamma = invgamma_gen(a=0.0, name='invgamma')
4967 
4968 
4969 class invgauss_gen(rv_continuous):
4970     r"""An inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 
4971  
4972     %(before_notes)s 
4973  
4974     Notes 
4975     ----- 
4976     The probability density function for `invgauss` is: 
4977  
4978     .. math:: 
4979  
4980         f(x; \mu) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi x^3}} 
4981                     \exp\left(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2 \mu^2 x}\right) 
4982  
4983     for :math:`x \ge 0` and :math:`\mu > 0`. 
4984  
4985     `invgauss` takes ``mu`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\mu`. 
4986  
4987     %(after_notes)s 
4988  
4989     A common shape-scale parameterization of the inverse Gaussian distribution 
4990     has density 
4991  
4992     .. math:: 
4993  
4994         f(x; \nu, \lambda) = \sqrt{\frac{\lambda}{2 \pi x^3}} 
4995                     \exp\left( -\frac{\lambda(x-\nu)^2}{2 \nu^2 x}\right) 
4996  
4997     Using ``nu`` for :math:`\nu` and ``lam`` for :math:`\lambda`, this 
4998     parameterization is equivalent to the one above with ``mu = nu/lam``, 
4999     ``loc = 0``, and ``scale = lam``. 
5000  
5001     This distribution uses routines from the Boost Math C++ library for 
5002     the computation of the ``ppf`` and ``isf`` methods. [1]_ 
5003  
5004     References 
5005     ---------- 
5006     .. [1] The Boost Developers. "Boost C++ Libraries". https://www.boost.org/. 
5007  
5008     %(example)s 
5009  
5010     """
5011     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5012 
5013     def _shape_info(self):
5014         return [_ShapeInfo("mu", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
5015 
5016     def _rvs(self, mu, size=None, random_state=None):
5017         return random_state.wald(mu, 1.0, size=size)
5018 
5019     def _pdf(self, x, mu):
5020         # invgauss.pdf(x, mu) =
5021         #                  1 / sqrt(2*pi*x**3) * exp(-(x-mu)**2/(2*x*mu**2))
5022         return 1.0/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x**3.0)*np.exp(-1.0/(2*x)*((x-mu)/mu)**2)
5023 
5024     def _logpdf(self, x, mu):
5025         return -0.5*np.log(2*np.pi) - 1.5*np.log(x) - ((x-mu)/mu)**2/(2*x)
5026 
5027     # approach adapted from equations in
5028     # https://journal.r-project.org/archive/2016-1/giner-smyth.pdf,
5029     # not R code. see gh-13616
5030 
5031     def _logcdf(self, x, mu):
5032         fac = 1 / np.sqrt(x)
5033         a = _norm_logcdf(fac * ((x / mu) - 1))
5034         b = 2 / mu + _norm_logcdf(-fac * ((x / mu) + 1))
5035         return a + np.log1p(np.exp(b - a))
5036 
5037     def _logsf(self, x, mu):
5038         fac = 1 / np.sqrt(x)
5039         a = _norm_logsf(fac * ((x / mu) - 1))
5040         b = 2 / mu + _norm_logcdf(-fac * (x + mu) / mu)
5041         return a + np.log1p(-np.exp(b - a))
5042 
5043     def _sf(self, x, mu):
5044         return np.exp(self._logsf(x, mu))
5045 
5046     def _cdf(self, x, mu):
5047         return np.exp(self._logcdf(x, mu))
5048 
5049     def _ppf(self, x, mu):
5050         with np.errstate(divide='ignore', over='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
5051             x, mu = np.broadcast_arrays(x, mu)
5052             ppf = np.asarray(scu._invgauss_ppf(x, mu, 1))
5053             i_wt = x > 0.5  # "wrong tail" - sometimes too inaccurate
5054             ppf[i_wt] = scu._invgauss_isf(1-x[i_wt], mu[i_wt], 1)
5055             i_nan = np.isnan(ppf)
5056             ppf[i_nan] = super()._ppf(x[i_nan], mu[i_nan])
5057         return ppf
5058 
5059     def _isf(self, x, mu):
5060         with np.errstate(divide='ignore', over='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
5061             x, mu = np.broadcast_arrays(x, mu)
5062             isf = scu._invgauss_isf(x, mu, 1)
5063             i_wt = x > 0.5  # "wrong tail" - sometimes too inaccurate
5064             isf[i_wt] = scu._invgauss_ppf(1-x[i_wt], mu[i_wt], 1)
5065             i_nan = np.isnan(isf)
5066             isf[i_nan] = super()._isf(x[i_nan], mu[i_nan])
5067         return isf
5068 
5069     def _stats(self, mu):
5070         return mu, mu**3.0, 3*np.sqrt(mu), 15*mu
5071 
5072     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
5073     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
5074         method = kwds.get('method', 'mle')
5075 
5076         if (isinstance(data, CensoredData) or isinstance(self, wald_gen)
5077                 or method.lower() == 'mm'):
5078             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
5079 
5080         data, fshape_s, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
5081                                                                    args, kwds)
5082         ''' 
5083         Source: Statistical Distributions, 3rd Edition. Evans, Hastings, 
5084         and Peacock (2000), Page 121. Their shape parameter is equivalent to 
5085         SciPy's with the conversion `fshape_s = fshape / scale`. 
5086  
5087         MLE formulas are not used in 3 conditions: 
5088         - `loc` is not fixed 
5089         - `mu` is fixed 
5090         These cases fall back on the superclass fit method. 
5091         - `loc` is fixed but translation results in negative data raises 
5092           a `FitDataError`. 
5093         '''
5094         if floc is None or fshape_s is not None:
5095             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
5096         elif np.any(data - floc < 0):
5097             raise FitDataError("invgauss", lower=0, upper=np.inf)
5098         else:
5099             data = data - floc
5100             fshape_n = np.mean(data)
5101             if fscale is None:
5102                 fscale = len(data) / (np.sum(data ** -1 - fshape_n ** -1))
5103             fshape_s = fshape_n / fscale
5104         return fshape_s, floc, fscale
5105 
5106     def _entropy(self, mu):
5107         """ 
5108         Ref.: https://moser-isi.ethz.ch/docs/papers/smos-2012-10.pdf (eq. 9) 
5109         """
5110         # a = log(2*pi*e*mu**3)
5111         #   = 1 + log(2*pi) + 3 * log(mu)
5112         a = 1. + np.log(2 * np.pi) + 3 * np.log(mu)
5113         # b = exp(2/mu) * exp1(2/mu)
5114         #   = _scaled_exp1(2/mu) / (2/mu)
5115         r = 2/mu
5116         b = sc._ufuncs._scaled_exp1(r)/r
5117         return 0.5 * a - 1.5 * b
5118 
5119 
5120 invgauss = invgauss_gen(a=0.0, name='invgauss')
5121 
5122 
5123 class geninvgauss_gen(rv_continuous):
5124     r"""A Generalized Inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 
5125  
5126     %(before_notes)s 
5127  
5128     Notes 
5129     ----- 
5130     The probability density function for `geninvgauss` is: 
5131  
5132     .. math:: 
5133  
5134         f(x, p, b) = x^{p-1} \exp(-b (x + 1/x) / 2) / (2 K_p(b)) 
5135  
5136     where ``x > 0``, `p` is a real number and ``b > 0``\([1]_). 
5137     :math:`K_p` is the modified Bessel function of second kind of order `p` 
5138     (`scipy.special.kv`). 
5139  
5140     %(after_notes)s 
5141  
5142     The inverse Gaussian distribution `stats.invgauss(mu)` is a special case of 
5143     `geninvgauss` with ``p = -1/2``, ``b = 1 / mu`` and ``scale = mu``. 
5144  
5145     Generating random variates is challenging for this distribution. The 
5146     implementation is based on [2]_. 
5147  
5148     References 
5149     ---------- 
5150     .. [1] O. Barndorff-Nielsen, P. Blaesild, C. Halgreen, "First hitting time 
5151        models for the generalized inverse gaussian distribution", 
5152        Stochastic Processes and their Applications 7, pp. 49--54, 1978. 
5153  
5154     .. [2] W. Hoermann and J. Leydold, "Generating generalized inverse Gaussian 
5155        random variates", Statistics and Computing, 24(4), p. 547--557, 2014. 
5156  
5157     %(example)s 
5158  
5159     """
5160     def _argcheck(self, p, b):
5161         return (p == p) & (b > 0)
5162 
5163     def _shape_info(self):
5164         ip = _ShapeInfo("p", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5165         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5166         return [ip, ib]
5167 
5168     def _logpdf(self, x, p, b):
5169         # kve instead of kv works better for large values of b
5170         # warn if kve produces infinite values and replace by nan
5171         # otherwise c = -inf and the results are often incorrect
5172         def logpdf_single(x, p, b):
5173             return _stats.geninvgauss_logpdf(x, p, b)
5174 
5175         logpdf_single = np.vectorize(logpdf_single, otypes=[np.float64])
5176 
5177         z = logpdf_single(x, p, b)
5178         if np.isnan(z).any():
5179             msg = ("Infinite values encountered in scipy.special.kve(p, b). "
5180                    "Values replaced by NaN to avoid incorrect results.")
5181             warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=3)
5182         return z
5183 
5184     def _pdf(self, x, p, b):
5185         # relying on logpdf avoids overflow of x**(p-1) for large x and p
5186         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, p, b))
5187 
5188     def _cdf(self, x, p, b):
5189         _a, _b = self._get_support(p, b)
5190 
5191         def _cdf_single(x, p, b):
5192             user_data = np.array([p, b], float).ctypes.data_as(ctypes.c_void_p)
5193             llc = LowLevelCallable.from_cython(_stats, '_geninvgauss_pdf',
5194                                                user_data)
5195 
5196             return integrate.quad(llc, _a, x)[0]
5197 
5198         _cdf_single = np.vectorize(_cdf_single, otypes=[np.float64])
5199 
5200         return _cdf_single(x, p, b)
5201 
5202     def _logquasipdf(self, x, p, b):
5203         # log of the quasi-density (w/o normalizing constant) used in _rvs
5204         return _lazywhere(x > 0, (x, p, b),
5205                           lambda x, p, b: (p - 1)*np.log(x) - b*(x + 1/x)/2,
5206                           -np.inf)
5207 
5208     def _rvs(self, p, b, size=None, random_state=None):
5209         # if p and b are scalar, use _rvs_scalar, otherwise need to create
5210         # output by iterating over parameters
5211         if np.isscalar(p) and np.isscalar(b):
5212             out = self._rvs_scalar(p, b, size, random_state)
5213         elif p.size == 1 and b.size == 1:
5214             out = self._rvs_scalar(p.item(), b.item(), size, random_state)
5215         else:
5216             # When this method is called, size will be a (possibly empty)
5217             # tuple of integers.  It will not be None; if `size=None` is passed
5218             # to `rvs()`, size will be the empty tuple ().
5219 
5220             p, b = np.broadcast_arrays(p, b)
5221             # p and b now have the same shape.
5222 
5223             # `shp` is the shape of the blocks of random variates that are
5224             # generated for each combination of parameters associated with
5225             # broadcasting p and b.
5226             # bc is a tuple the same length as size.  The values
5227             # in bc are bools.  If bc[j] is True, it means that
5228             # entire axis is filled in for a given combination of the
5229             # broadcast arguments.
5230             shp, bc = _check_shape(p.shape, size)
5231 
5232             # `numsamples` is the total number of variates to be generated
5233             # for each combination of the input arguments.
5234             numsamples = int(np.prod(shp))
5235 
5236             # `out` is the array to be returned.  It is filled in the
5237             # loop below.
5238             out = np.empty(size)
5239 
5240             it = np.nditer([p, b],
5241                            flags=['multi_index'],
5242                            op_flags=[['readonly'], ['readonly']])
5243             while not it.finished:
5244                 # Convert the iterator's multi_index into an index into the
5245                 # `out` array where the call to _rvs_scalar() will be stored.
5246                 # Where bc is True, we use a full slice; otherwise we use the
5247                 # index value from it.multi_index.  len(it.multi_index) might
5248                 # be less than len(bc), and in that case we want to align these
5249                 # two sequences to the right, so the loop variable j runs from
5250                 # -len(size) to 0.  This doesn't cause an IndexError, as
5251                 # bc[j] will be True in those cases where it.multi_index[j]
5252                 # would cause an IndexError.
5253                 idx = tuple((it.multi_index[j] if not bc[j] else slice(None))
5254                             for j in range(-len(size), 0))
5255                 out[idx] = self._rvs_scalar(it[0], it[1], numsamples,
5256                                             random_state).reshape(shp)
5257                 it.iternext()
5258 
5259         if size == ():
5260             out = out.item()
5261         return out
5262 
5263     def _rvs_scalar(self, p, b, numsamples, random_state):
5264         # following [2], the quasi-pdf is used instead of the pdf for the
5265         # generation of rvs
5266         invert_res = False
5267         if not numsamples:
5268             numsamples = 1
5269         if p < 0:
5270             # note: if X is geninvgauss(p, b), then 1/X is geninvgauss(-p, b)
5271             p = -p
5272             invert_res = True
5273         m = self._mode(p, b)
5274 
5275         # determine method to be used following [2]
5276         ratio_unif = True
5277         if p >= 1 or b > 1:
5278             # ratio of uniforms with mode shift below
5279             mode_shift = True
5280         elif b >= min(0.5, 2 * np.sqrt(1 - p) / 3):
5281             # ratio of uniforms without mode shift below
5282             mode_shift = False
5283         else:
5284             # new algorithm in [2]
5285             ratio_unif = False
5286 
5287         # prepare sampling of rvs
5288         size1d = tuple(np.atleast_1d(numsamples))
5289         N = np.prod(size1d)  # number of rvs needed, reshape upon return
5290         x = np.zeros(N)
5291         simulated = 0
5292 
5293         if ratio_unif:
5294             # use ratio of uniforms method
5295             if mode_shift:
5296                 a2 = -2 * (p + 1) / b - m
5297                 a1 = 2 * m * (p - 1) / b - 1
5298                 # find roots of x**3 + a2*x**2 + a1*x + m (Cardano's formula)
5299                 p1 = a1 - a2**2 / 3
5300                 q1 = 2 * a2**3 / 27 - a2 * a1 / 3 + m
5301                 phi = np.arccos(-q1 * np.sqrt(-27 / p1**3) / 2)
5302                 s1 = -np.sqrt(-4 * p1 / 3)
5303                 root1 = s1 * np.cos(phi / 3 + np.pi / 3) - a2 / 3
5304                 root2 = -s1 * np.cos(phi / 3) - a2 / 3
5305                 # root3 = s1 * np.cos(phi / 3 - np.pi / 3) - a2 / 3
5306 
5307                 # if g is the quasipdf, rescale: g(x) / g(m) which we can write
5308                 # as exp(log(g(x)) - log(g(m))). This is important
5309                 # since for large values of p and b, g cannot be evaluated.
5310                 # denote the rescaled quasipdf by h
5311                 lm = self._logquasipdf(m, p, b)
5312                 d1 = self._logquasipdf(root1, p, b) - lm
5313                 d2 = self._logquasipdf(root2, p, b) - lm
5314                 # compute the bounding rectangle w.r.t. h. Note that
5315                 # np.exp(0.5*d1) = np.sqrt(g(root1)/g(m)) = np.sqrt(h(root1))
5316                 vmin = (root1 - m) * np.exp(0.5 * d1)
5317                 vmax = (root2 - m) * np.exp(0.5 * d2)
5318                 umax = 1  # umax = sqrt(h(m)) = 1
5319 
5320                 def logqpdf(x):
5321                     return self._logquasipdf(x, p, b) - lm
5322 
5323                 c = m
5324             else:
5325                 # ratio of uniforms without mode shift
5326                 # compute np.sqrt(quasipdf(m))
5327                 umax = np.exp(0.5*self._logquasipdf(m, p, b))
5328                 xplus = ((1 + p) + np.sqrt((1 + p)**2 + b**2))/b
5329                 vmin = 0
5330                 # compute xplus * np.sqrt(quasipdf(xplus))
5331                 vmax = xplus * np.exp(0.5 * self._logquasipdf(xplus, p, b))
5332                 c = 0
5333 
5334                 def logqpdf(x):
5335                     return self._logquasipdf(x, p, b)
5336 
5337             if vmin >= vmax:
5338                 raise ValueError("vmin must be smaller than vmax.")
5339             if umax <= 0:
5340                 raise ValueError("umax must be positive.")
5341 
5342             i = 1
5343             while simulated < N:
5344                 k = N - simulated
5345                 # simulate uniform rvs on [0, umax] and [vmin, vmax]
5346                 u = umax * random_state.uniform(size=k)
5347                 v = random_state.uniform(size=k)
5348                 v = vmin + (vmax - vmin) * v
5349                 rvs = v / u + c
5350                 # rewrite acceptance condition u**2 <= pdf(rvs) by taking logs
5351                 accept = (2*np.log(u) <= logqpdf(rvs))
5352                 num_accept = np.sum(accept)
5353                 if num_accept > 0:
5354                     x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs[accept]
5355                     simulated += num_accept
5356 
5357                 if (simulated == 0) and (i*N >= 50000):
5358                     msg = ("Not a single random variate could be generated "
5359                            f"in {i*N} attempts. Sampling does not appear to "
5360                            "work for the provided parameters.")
5361                     raise RuntimeError(msg)
5362                 i += 1
5363         else:
5364             # use new algorithm in [2]
5365             x0 = b / (1 - p)
5366             xs = np.max((x0, 2 / b))
5367             k1 = np.exp(self._logquasipdf(m, p, b))
5368             A1 = k1 * x0
5369             if x0 < 2 / b:
5370                 k2 = np.exp(-b)
5371                 if p > 0:
5372                     A2 = k2 * ((2 / b)**p - x0**p) / p
5373                 else:
5374                     A2 = k2 * np.log(2 / b**2)
5375             else:
5376                 k2, A2 = 0, 0
5377             k3 = xs**(p - 1)
5378             A3 = 2 * k3 * np.exp(-xs * b / 2) / b
5379             A = A1 + A2 + A3
5380 
5381             # [2]: rejection constant is < 2.73; so expected runtime is finite
5382             while simulated < N:
5383                 k = N - simulated
5384                 h, rvs = np.zeros(k), np.zeros(k)
5385                 # simulate uniform rvs on [x1, x2] and [0, y2]
5386                 u = random_state.uniform(size=k)
5387                 v = A * random_state.uniform(size=k)
5388                 cond1 = v <= A1
5389                 cond2 = np.logical_not(cond1) & (v <= A1 + A2)
5390                 cond3 = np.logical_not(cond1 | cond2)
5391                 # subdomain (0, x0)
5392                 rvs[cond1] = x0 * v[cond1] / A1
5393                 h[cond1] = k1
5394                 # subdomain (x0, 2 / b)
5395                 if p > 0:
5396                     rvs[cond2] = (x0**p + (v[cond2] - A1) * p / k2)**(1 / p)
5397                 else:
5398                     rvs[cond2] = b * np.exp((v[cond2] - A1) * np.exp(b))
5399                 h[cond2] = k2 * rvs[cond2]**(p - 1)
5400                 # subdomain (xs, infinity)
5401                 z = np.exp(-xs * b / 2) - b * (v[cond3] - A1 - A2) / (2 * k3)
5402                 rvs[cond3] = -2 / b * np.log(z)
5403                 h[cond3] = k3 * np.exp(-rvs[cond3] * b / 2)
5404                 # apply rejection method
5405                 accept = (np.log(u * h) <= self._logquasipdf(rvs, p, b))
5406                 num_accept = sum(accept)
5407                 if num_accept > 0:
5408                     x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs[accept]
5409                     simulated += num_accept
5410 
5411         rvs = np.reshape(x, size1d)
5412         if invert_res:
5413             rvs = 1 / rvs
5414         return rvs
5415 
5416     def _mode(self, p, b):
5417         # distinguish cases to avoid catastrophic cancellation (see [2])
5418         if p < 1:
5419             return b / (np.sqrt((p - 1)**2 + b**2) + 1 - p)
5420         else:
5421             return (np.sqrt((1 - p)**2 + b**2) - (1 - p)) / b
5422 
5423     def _munp(self, n, p, b):
5424         num = sc.kve(p + n, b)
5425         denom = sc.kve(p, b)
5426         inf_vals = np.isinf(num) | np.isinf(denom)
5427         if inf_vals.any():
5428             msg = ("Infinite values encountered in the moment calculation "
5429                    "involving scipy.special.kve. Values replaced by NaN to "
5430                    "avoid incorrect results.")
5431             warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=3)
5432             m = np.full_like(num, np.nan, dtype=np.float64)
5433             m[~inf_vals] = num[~inf_vals] / denom[~inf_vals]
5434         else:
5435             m = num / denom
5436         return m
5437 
5438 
5439 geninvgauss = geninvgauss_gen(a=0.0, name="geninvgauss")
5440 
5441 
5442 class norminvgauss_gen(rv_continuous):
5443     r"""A Normal Inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 
5444  
5445     %(before_notes)s 
5446  
5447     Notes 
5448     ----- 
5449     The probability density function for `norminvgauss` is: 
5450  
5451     .. math:: 
5452  
5453         f(x, a, b) = \frac{a \, K_1(a \sqrt{1 + x^2})}{\pi \sqrt{1 + x^2}} \, 
5454                      \exp(\sqrt{a^2 - b^2} + b x) 
5455  
5456     where :math:`x` is a real number, the parameter :math:`a` is the tail 
5457     heaviness and :math:`b` is the asymmetry parameter satisfying 
5458     :math:`a > 0` and :math:`|b| <= a`. 
5459     :math:`K_1` is the modified Bessel function of second kind 
5460     (`scipy.special.k1`). 
5461  
5462     %(after_notes)s 
5463  
5464     A normal inverse Gaussian random variable `Y` with parameters `a` and `b` 
5465     can be expressed as a normal mean-variance mixture: 
5466     ``Y = b * V + sqrt(V) * X`` where `X` is ``norm(0,1)`` and `V` is 
5467     ``invgauss(mu=1/sqrt(a**2 - b**2))``. This representation is used 
5468     to generate random variates. 
5469  
5470     Another common parametrization of the distribution (see Equation 2.1 in 
5471     [2]_) is given by the following expression of the pdf: 
5472  
5473     .. math:: 
5474  
5475         g(x, \alpha, \beta, \delta, \mu) = 
5476         \frac{\alpha\delta K_1\left(\alpha\sqrt{\delta^2 + (x - \mu)^2}\right)} 
5477         {\pi \sqrt{\delta^2 + (x - \mu)^2}} \, 
5478         e^{\delta \sqrt{\alpha^2 - \beta^2} + \beta (x - \mu)} 
5479  
5480     In SciPy, this corresponds to 
5481     `a = alpha * delta, b = beta * delta, loc = mu, scale=delta`. 
5482  
5483     References 
5484     ---------- 
5485     .. [1] O. Barndorff-Nielsen, "Hyperbolic Distributions and Distributions on 
5486            Hyperbolae", Scandinavian Journal of Statistics, Vol. 5(3), 
5487            pp. 151-157, 1978. 
5488  
5489     .. [2] O. Barndorff-Nielsen, "Normal Inverse Gaussian Distributions and 
5490            Stochastic Volatility Modelling", Scandinavian Journal of 
5491            Statistics, Vol. 24, pp. 1-13, 1997. 
5492  
5493     %(example)s 
5494  
5495     """
5496     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5497 
5498     def _argcheck(self, a, b):
5499         return (a > 0) & (np.absolute(b) < a)
5500 
5501     def _shape_info(self):
5502         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5503         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5504         return [ia, ib]
5505 
5506     def _fitstart(self, data):
5507         # Arbitrary, but the default a = b = 1 is not valid; the distribution
5508         # requires |b| < a.
5509         return super()._fitstart(data, args=(1, 0.5))
5510 
5511     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5512         gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2)
5513         fac1 = a / np.pi
5514         sq = np.hypot(1, x)  # reduce overflows
5515         return fac1 * sc.k1e(a * sq) * np.exp(b*x - a*sq + gamma) / sq
5516 
5517     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5518         if np.isscalar(x):
5519             # If x is a scalar, then so are a and b.
5520             return integrate.quad(self._pdf, x, np.inf, args=(a, b))[0]
5521         else:
5522             a = np.atleast_1d(a)
5523             b = np.atleast_1d(b)
5524             result = []
5525             for (x0, a0, b0) in zip(x, a, b):
5526                 result.append(integrate.quad(self._pdf, x0, np.inf,
5527                                              args=(a0, b0))[0])
5528             return np.array(result)
5529 
5530     def _isf(self, q, a, b):
5531         def _isf_scalar(q, a, b):
5532 
5533             def eq(x, a, b, q):
5534                 # Solve eq(x, a, b, q) = 0 to obtain isf(x, a, b) = q.
5535                 return self._sf(x, a, b) - q
5536 
5537             # Find a bracketing interval for the root.
5538             # Start at the mean, and grow the length of the interval
5539             # by 2 each iteration until there is a sign change in eq.
5540             xm = self.mean(a, b)
5541             em = eq(xm, a, b, q)
5542             if em == 0:
5543                 # Unlikely, but might as well check.
5544                 return xm
5545             if em > 0:
5546                 delta = 1
5547                 left = xm
5548                 right = xm + delta
5549                 while eq(right, a, b, q) > 0:
5550                     delta = 2*delta
5551                     right = xm + delta
5552             else:
5553                 # em < 0
5554                 delta = 1
5555                 right = xm
5556                 left = xm - delta
5557                 while eq(left, a, b, q) < 0:
5558                     delta = 2*delta
5559                     left = xm - delta
5560             result = optimize.brentq(eq, left, right, args=(a, b, q),
5561                                      xtol=self.xtol)
5562             return result
5563 
5564         if np.isscalar(q):
5565             return _isf_scalar(q, a, b)
5566         else:
5567             result = []
5568             for (q0, a0, b0) in zip(q, a, b):
5569                 result.append(_isf_scalar(q0, a0, b0))
5570             return np.array(result)
5571 
5572     def _rvs(self, a, b, size=None, random_state=None):
5573         # note: X = b * V + sqrt(V) * X is norminvgaus(a,b) if X is standard
5574         # normal and V is invgauss(mu=1/sqrt(a**2 - b**2))
5575         gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2)
5576         ig = invgauss.rvs(mu=1/gamma, size=size, random_state=random_state)
5577         return b * ig + np.sqrt(ig) * norm.rvs(size=size,
5578                                                random_state=random_state)
5579 
5580     def _stats(self, a, b):
5581         gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2)
5582         mean = b / gamma
5583         variance = a**2 / gamma**3
5584         skewness = 3.0 * b / (a * np.sqrt(gamma))
5585         kurtosis = 3.0 * (1 + 4 * b**2 / a**2) / gamma
5586         return mean, variance, skewness, kurtosis
5587 
5588 
5589 norminvgauss = norminvgauss_gen(name="norminvgauss")
5590 
5591 
5592 class invweibull_gen(rv_continuous):
5593     """An inverted Weibull continuous random variable. 
5594  
5595     This distribution is also known as the Fréchet distribution or the 
5596     type II extreme value distribution. 
5597  
5598     %(before_notes)s 
5599  
5600     Notes 
5601     ----- 
5602     The probability density function for `invweibull` is: 
5603  
5604     .. math:: 
5605  
5606         f(x, c) = c x^{-c-1} \\exp(-x^{-c}) 
5607  
5608     for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 
5609  
5610     `invweibull` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 
5611  
5612     %(after_notes)s 
5613  
5614     References 
5615     ---------- 
5616     F.R.S. de Gusmao, E.M.M Ortega and G.M. Cordeiro, "The generalized inverse 
5617     Weibull distribution", Stat. Papers, vol. 52, pp. 591-619, 2011. 
5618  
5619     %(example)s 
5620  
5621     """
5622     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5623 
5624     def _shape_info(self):
5625         return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
5626 
5627     def _pdf(self, x, c):
5628         # invweibull.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(-c-1) * exp(-x**(-c))
5629         xc1 = np.power(x, -c - 1.0)
5630         xc2 = np.power(x, -c)
5631         xc2 = np.exp(-xc2)
5632         return c * xc1 * xc2
5633 
5634     def _cdf(self, x, c):
5635         xc1 = np.power(x, -c)
5636         return np.exp(-xc1)
5637 
5638     def _sf(self, x, c):
5639         return -np.expm1(-x**-c)
5640 
5641     def _ppf(self, q, c):
5642         return np.power(-np.log(q), -1.0/c)
5643 
5644     def _isf(self, p, c):
5645         return (-np.log1p(-p))**(-1/c)
5646 
5647     def _munp(self, n, c):
5648         return sc.gamma(1 - n / c)
5649 
5650     def _entropy(self, c):
5651         return 1+_EULER + _EULER / c - np.log(c)
5652 
5653     def _fitstart(self, data, args=None):
5654         # invweibull requires c > 1 for the first moment to exist, so use 2.0
5655         args = (2.0,) if args is None else args
5656         return super()._fitstart(data, args=args)
5657 
5658 
5659 invweibull = invweibull_gen(a=0, name='invweibull')
5660 
5661 
5662 class jf_skew_t_gen(rv_continuous):
5663     r"""Jones and Faddy skew-t distribution. 
5664  
5665     %(before_notes)s 
5666  
5667     Notes 
5668     ----- 
5669     The probability density function for `jf_skew_t` is: 
5670  
5671     .. math:: 
5672  
5673         f(x; a, b) = C_{a,b}^{-1} 
5674                     \left(1+\frac{x}{\left(a+b+x^2\right)^{1/2}}\right)^{a+1/2} 
5675                     \left(1-\frac{x}{\left(a+b+x^2\right)^{1/2}}\right)^{b+1/2} 
5676  
5677     for real numbers :math:`a>0` and :math:`b>0`, where 
5678     :math:`C_{a,b} = 2^{a+b-1}B(a,b)(a+b)^{1/2}`, and :math:`B` denotes the 
5679     beta function (`scipy.special.beta`). 
5680  
5681     When :math:`a<b`, the distribution is negatively skewed, and when 
5682     :math:`a>b`, the distribution is positively skewed. If :math:`a=b`, then 
5683     we recover the `t` distribution with :math:`2a` degrees of freedom. 
5684  
5685     `jf_skew_t` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 
5686  
5687     %(after_notes)s 
5688  
5689     References 
5690     ---------- 
5691     .. [1] M.C. Jones and M.J. Faddy. "A skew extension of the t distribution, 
5692            with applications" *Journal of the Royal Statistical Society*. 
5693            Series B (Statistical Methodology) 65, no. 1 (2003): 159-174. 
5694            :doi:`10.1111/1467-9868.00378` 
5695  
5696     %(example)s 
5697  
5698     """
5699     def _shape_info(self):
5700         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5701         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5702         return [ia, ib]
5703 
5704     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5705         c = 2 ** (a + b - 1) * sc.beta(a, b) * np.sqrt(a + b)
5706         d1 = (1 + x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) ** (a + 0.5)
5707         d2 = (1 - x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) ** (b + 0.5)
5708         return d1 * d2 / c
5709 
5710     def _rvs(self, a, b, size=None, random_state=None):
5711         d1 = random_state.beta(a, b, size)
5712         d2 = (2 * d1 - 1) * np.sqrt(a + b)
5713         d3 = 2 * np.sqrt(d1 * (1 - d1))
5714         return d2 / d3
5715 
5716     def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
5717         y = (1 + x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) * 0.5
5718         return sc.betainc(a, b, y)
5719 
5720     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5721         y = (1 + x / np.sqrt(a + b + x ** 2)) * 0.5
5722         return sc.betaincc(a, b, y)
5723 
5724     def _ppf(self, q, a, b):
5725         d1 = beta.ppf(q, a, b)
5726         d2 = (2 * d1 - 1) * np.sqrt(a + b)
5727         d3 = 2 * np.sqrt(d1 * (1 - d1))
5728         return d2 / d3
5729 
5730     def _munp(self, n, a, b):
5731         """Returns the n-th moment(s) where all the following hold: 
5732  
5733         - n >= 0 
5734         - a > n / 2 
5735         - b > n / 2 
5736  
5737         The result is np.nan in all other cases. 
5738         """
5739         def nth_moment(n_k, a_k, b_k):
5740             """Computes E[T^(n_k)] where T is skew-t distributed with 
5741             parameters a_k and b_k. 
5742             """
5743             num = (a_k + b_k) ** (0.5 * n_k)
5744             denom = 2 ** n_k * sc.beta(a_k, b_k)
5745 
5746             indices = np.arange(n_k + 1)
5747             sgn = np.where(indices % 2 > 0, -1, 1)
5748             d = sc.beta(a_k + 0.5 * n_k - indices, b_k - 0.5 * n_k + indices)
5749             sum_terms = sc.comb(n_k, indices) * sgn * d
5750 
5751             return num / denom * sum_terms.sum()
5752 
5753         nth_moment_valid = (a > 0.5 * n) & (b > 0.5 * n) & (n >= 0)
5754         return _lazywhere(
5755             nth_moment_valid,
5756             (n, a, b),
5757             np.vectorize(nth_moment, otypes=[np.float64]),
5758             np.nan,
5759         )
5760 
5761 
5762 jf_skew_t = jf_skew_t_gen(name='jf_skew_t')
5763 
5764 
5765 class johnsonsb_gen(rv_continuous):
5766     r"""A Johnson SB continuous random variable. 
5767  
5768     %(before_notes)s 
5769  
5770     See Also 
5771     -------- 
5772     johnsonsu 
5773  
5774     Notes 
5775     ----- 
5776     The probability density function for `johnsonsb` is: 
5777  
5778     .. math:: 
5779  
5780         f(x, a, b) = \frac{b}{x(1-x)}  \phi(a + b \log \frac{x}{1-x} ) 
5781  
5782     where :math:`x`, :math:`a`, and :math:`b` are real scalars; :math:`b > 0` 
5783     and :math:`x \in [0,1]`.  :math:`\phi` is the pdf of the normal 
5784     distribution. 
5785  
5786     `johnsonsb` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 
5787  
5788     %(after_notes)s 
5789  
5790     %(example)s 
5791  
5792     """
5793     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
5794 
5795     def _argcheck(self, a, b):
5796         return (b > 0) & (a == a)
5797 
5798     def _shape_info(self):
5799         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5800         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5801         return [ia, ib]
5802 
5803     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5804         # johnsonsb.pdf(x, a, b) = b / (x*(1-x)) * phi(a + b * log(x/(1-x)))
5805         trm = _norm_pdf(a + b*sc.logit(x))
5806         return b*1.0/(x*(1-x))*trm
5807 
5808     def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
5809         return _norm_cdf(a + b*sc.logit(x))
5810 
5811     def _ppf(self, q, a, b):
5812         return sc.expit(1.0 / b * (_norm_ppf(q) - a))
5813 
5814     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5815         return _norm_sf(a + b*sc.logit(x))
5816 
5817     def _isf(self, q, a, b):
5818         return sc.expit(1.0 / b * (_norm_isf(q) - a))
5819 
5820 
5821 johnsonsb = johnsonsb_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='johnsonsb')
5822 
5823 
5824 class johnsonsu_gen(rv_continuous):
5825     r"""A Johnson SU continuous random variable. 
5826  
5827     %(before_notes)s 
5828  
5829     See Also 
5830     -------- 
5831     johnsonsb 
5832  
5833     Notes 
5834     ----- 
5835     The probability density function for `johnsonsu` is: 
5836  
5837     .. math:: 
5838  
5839         f(x, a, b) = \frac{b}{\sqrt{x^2 + 1}} 
5840                      \phi(a + b \log(x + \sqrt{x^2 + 1})) 
5841  
5842     where :math:`x`, :math:`a`, and :math:`b` are real scalars; :math:`b > 0`. 
5843     :math:`\phi` is the pdf of the normal distribution. 
5844  
5845     `johnsonsu` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 
5846  
5847     The first four central moments are calculated according to the formulas 
5848     in [1]_. 
5849  
5850     %(after_notes)s 
5851  
5852     References 
5853     ---------- 
5854     .. [1] Taylor Enterprises. "Johnson Family of Distributions". 
5855        https://variation.com/wp-content/distribution_analyzer_help/hs126.htm 
5856  
5857     %(example)s 
5858  
5859     """
5860     def _argcheck(self, a, b):
5861         return (b > 0) & (a == a)
5862 
5863     def _shape_info(self):
5864         ia = _ShapeInfo("a", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))
5865         ib = _ShapeInfo("b", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
5866         return [ia, ib]
5867 
5868     def _pdf(self, x, a, b):
5869         # johnsonsu.pdf(x, a, b) = b / sqrt(x**2 + 1) *
5870         #                          phi(a + b * log(x + sqrt(x**2 + 1)))
5871         x2 = x*x
5872         trm = _norm_pdf(a + b * np.arcsinh(x))
5873         return b*1.0/np.sqrt(x2+1.0)*trm
5874 
5875     def _cdf(self, x, a, b):
5876         return _norm_cdf(a + b * np.arcsinh(x))
5877 
5878     def _ppf(self, q, a, b):
5879         return np.sinh((_norm_ppf(q) - a) / b)
5880 
5881     def _sf(self, x, a, b):
5882         return _norm_sf(a + b * np.arcsinh(x))
5883 
5884     def _isf(self, x, a, b):
5885         return np.sinh((_norm_isf(x) - a) / b)
5886 
5887     def _stats(self, a, b, moments='mv'):
5888         # Naive implementation of first and second moment to address gh-18071.
5889         # https://variation.com/wp-content/distribution_analyzer_help/hs126.htm
5890         # Numerical improvements left to future enhancements.
5891         mu, mu2, g1, g2 = None, None, None, None
5892 
5893         bn2 = b**-2.
5894         expbn2 = np.exp(bn2)
5895         a_b = a / b
5896 
5897         if 'm' in moments:
5898             mu = -expbn2**0.5 * np.sinh(a_b)
5899         if 'v' in moments:
5900             mu2 = 0.5*sc.expm1(bn2)*(expbn2*np.cosh(2*a_b) + 1)
5901         if 's' in moments:
5902             t1 = expbn2**.5 * sc.expm1(bn2)**0.5
5903             t2 = 3*np.sinh(a_b)
5904             t3 = expbn2 * (expbn2 + 2) * np.sinh(3*a_b)
5905             denom = np.sqrt(2) * (1 + expbn2 * np.cosh(2*a_b))**(3/2)
5906             g1 = -t1 * (t2 + t3) / denom
5907         if 'k' in moments:
5908             t1 = 3 + 6*expbn2
5909             t2 = 4*expbn2**2 * (expbn2 + 2) * np.cosh(2*a_b)
5910             t3 = expbn2**2 * np.cosh(4*a_b)
5911             t4 = -3 + 3*expbn2**2 + 2*expbn2**3 + expbn2**4
5912             denom = 2*(1 + expbn2*np.cosh(2*a_b))**2
5913             g2 = (t1 + t2 + t3*t4) / denom - 3
5914         return mu, mu2, g1, g2
5915 
5916 
5917 johnsonsu = johnsonsu_gen(name='johnsonsu')
5918 
5919 
5920 class landau_gen(rv_continuous):
5921     r"""A Landau continuous random variable. 
5922  
5923     %(before_notes)s 
5924  
5925     Notes 
5926     ----- 
5927     The probability density function for `landau` ([1]_, [2]_) is: 
5928  
5929     .. math:: 
5930  
5931         f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^\infty \exp(-t \log t - xt)\sin(\pi t) dt 
5932  
5933     for a real number :math:`x`. 
5934  
5935     %(after_notes)s 
5936  
5937     Often (e.g. [2]_), the Landau distribution is parameterized in terms of a 
5938     location parameter :math:`\mu` and scale parameter :math:`c`, the latter of 
5939     which *also* introduces a location shift. If ``mu`` and ``c`` are used to 
5940     represent these parameters, this corresponds with SciPy's parameterization 
5941     with ``loc = mu + 2*c / np.pi * np.log(c)`` and ``scale = c``. 
5942  
5943     This distribution uses routines from the Boost Math C++ library for 
5944     the computation of the ``pdf``, ``cdf``, ``ppf``, ``sf`` and ``isf`` 
5945     methods. [1]_ 
5946  
5947     References 
5948     ---------- 
5949     .. [1] Landau, L. (1944). "On the energy loss of fast particles by 
5950            ionization". J. Phys. (USSR). 8: 201. 
5951     .. [2] "Landau Distribution", Wikipedia, 
5952            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landau_distribution 
5953     .. [3] Chambers, J. M., Mallows, C. L., & Stuck, B. (1976). 
5954            "A method for simulating stable random variables." 
5955            Journal of the American Statistical Association, 71(354), 340-344. 
5956     .. [4] The Boost Developers. "Boost C++ Libraries". https://www.boost.org/. 
5957     .. [5] Yoshimura, T. "Numerical Evaluation and High Precision Approximation 
5958            Formula for Landau Distribution". 
5959            :doi:`10.36227/techrxiv.171822215.53612870/v2` 
5960  
5961     %(example)s 
5962  
5963     """
5964     def _shape_info(self):
5965         return []
5966 
5967     def _entropy(self):
5968         # Computed with mpmath - see gh-19145
5969         return 2.37263644000448182
5970 
5971     def _pdf(self, x):
5972         return scu._landau_pdf(x, 0, 1)
5973 
5974     def _cdf(self, x):
5975         return scu._landau_cdf(x, 0, 1)
5976 
5977     def _sf(self, x):
5978         return scu._landau_sf(x, 0, 1)
5979 
5980     def _ppf(self, p):
5981         return scu._landau_ppf(p, 0, 1)
5982 
5983     def _isf(self, p):
5984         return scu._landau_isf(p, 0, 1)
5985 
5986     def _stats(self):
5987         return np.nan, np.nan, np.nan, np.nan
5988 
5989     def _munp(self, n):
5990         return np.nan if n > 0 else 1
5991 
5992     def _fitstart(self, data, args=None):
5993         # Initialize ML guesses using quartiles instead of moments.
5994         if isinstance(data, CensoredData):
5995             data = data._uncensor()
5996         p25, p50, p75 = np.percentile(data, [25, 50, 75])
5997         return p50, (p75 - p25)/2
5998 
5999     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6000         # Method from https://www.jstor.org/stable/2285309 Eq. 2.4
6001         pi_2 = np.pi / 2
6002         U = random_state.uniform(-np.pi / 2, np.pi / 2, size=size)
6003         W = random_state.standard_exponential(size=size)
6004         S = 2 / np.pi * ((pi_2 + U) * np.tan(U)
6005                          - np.log((pi_2 * W * np.cos(U)) / (pi_2 + U)))
6006         return S
6007 
6008 
6009 landau = landau_gen(name='landau')
6010 
6011 
6012 class laplace_gen(rv_continuous):
6013     r"""A Laplace continuous random variable. 
6014  
6015     %(before_notes)s 
6016  
6017     Notes 
6018     ----- 
6019     The probability density function for `laplace` is 
6020  
6021     .. math:: 
6022  
6023         f(x) = \frac{1}{2} \exp(-|x|) 
6024  
6025     for a real number :math:`x`. 
6026  
6027     %(after_notes)s 
6028  
6029     %(example)s 
6030  
6031     """
6032     def _shape_info(self):
6033         return []
6034 
6035     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6036         return random_state.laplace(0, 1, size=size)
6037 
6038     def _pdf(self, x):
6039         # laplace.pdf(x) = 1/2 * exp(-abs(x))
6040         return 0.5*np.exp(-abs(x))
6041 
6042     def _cdf(self, x):
6043         with np.errstate(over='ignore'):
6044             return np.where(x > 0, 1.0 - 0.5*np.exp(-x), 0.5*np.exp(x))
6045 
6046     def _sf(self, x):
6047         # By symmetry...
6048         return self._cdf(-x)
6049 
6050     def _ppf(self, q):
6051         return np.where(q > 0.5, -np.log(2*(1-q)), np.log(2*q))
6052 
6053     def _isf(self, q):
6054         # By symmetry...
6055         return -self._ppf(q)
6056 
6057     def _stats(self):
6058         return 0, 2, 0, 3
6059 
6060     def _entropy(self):
6061         return np.log(2)+1
6062 
6063     @_call_super_mom
6064     @replace_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 
6065         This function uses explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood 
6066         estimation of the Laplace distribution parameters, so the keyword 
6067         arguments `loc`, `scale`, and `optimizer` are ignored.\n\n""")
6068     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
6069         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
6070                                                          args, kwds)
6071 
6072         # Source: Statistical Distributions, 3rd Edition. Evans, Hastings,
6073         # and Peacock (2000), Page 124
6074 
6075         if floc is None:
6076             floc = np.median(data)
6077 
6078         if fscale is None:
6079             fscale = (np.sum(np.abs(data - floc))) / len(data)
6080 
6081         return floc, fscale
6082 
6083 
6084 laplace = laplace_gen(name='laplace')
6085 
6086 
6087 class laplace_asymmetric_gen(rv_continuous):
6088     r"""An asymmetric Laplace continuous random variable. 
6089  
6090     %(before_notes)s 
6091  
6092     See Also 
6093     -------- 
6094     laplace : Laplace distribution 
6095  
6096     Notes 
6097     ----- 
6098     The probability density function for `laplace_asymmetric` is 
6099  
6100     .. math:: 
6101  
6102        f(x, \kappa) &= \frac{1}{\kappa+\kappa^{-1}}\exp(-x\kappa),\quad x\ge0\\ 
6103                     &= \frac{1}{\kappa+\kappa^{-1}}\exp(x/\kappa),\quad x<0\\ 
6104  
6105     for :math:`-\infty < x < \infty`, :math:`\kappa > 0`. 
6106  
6107     `laplace_asymmetric` takes ``kappa`` as a shape parameter for 
6108     :math:`\kappa`. For :math:`\kappa = 1`, it is identical to a 
6109     Laplace distribution. 
6110  
6111     %(after_notes)s 
6112  
6113     Note that the scale parameter of some references is the reciprocal of 
6114     SciPy's ``scale``. For example, :math:`\lambda = 1/2` in the 
6115     parameterization of [1]_ is equivalent to ``scale = 2`` with 
6116     `laplace_asymmetric`. 
6117  
6118     References 
6119     ---------- 
6120     .. [1] "Asymmetric Laplace distribution", Wikipedia 
6121             https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asymmetric_Laplace_distribution 
6122  
6123     .. [2] Kozubowski TJ and Podgórski K. A Multivariate and 
6124            Asymmetric Generalization of Laplace Distribution, 
6125            Computational Statistics 15, 531--540 (2000). 
6126            :doi:`10.1007/PL00022717` 
6127  
6128     %(example)s 
6129  
6130     """
6131     def _shape_info(self):
6132         return [_ShapeInfo("kappa", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
6133 
6134     def _pdf(self, x, kappa):
6135         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, kappa))
6136 
6137     def _logpdf(self, x, kappa):
6138         kapinv = 1/kappa
6139         lPx = x * np.where(x >= 0, -kappa, kapinv)
6140         lPx -= np.log(kappa+kapinv)
6141         return lPx
6142 
6143     def _cdf(self, x, kappa):
6144         kapinv = 1/kappa
6145         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6146         return np.where(x >= 0,
6147                         1 - np.exp(-x*kappa)*(kapinv/kappkapinv),
6148                         np.exp(x*kapinv)*(kappa/kappkapinv))
6149 
6150     def _sf(self, x, kappa):
6151         kapinv = 1/kappa
6152         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6153         return np.where(x >= 0,
6154                         np.exp(-x*kappa)*(kapinv/kappkapinv),
6155                         1 - np.exp(x*kapinv)*(kappa/kappkapinv))
6156 
6157     def _ppf(self, q, kappa):
6158         kapinv = 1/kappa
6159         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6160         return np.where(q >= kappa/kappkapinv,
6161                         -np.log((1 - q)*kappkapinv*kappa)*kapinv,
6162                         np.log(q*kappkapinv/kappa)*kappa)
6163 
6164     def _isf(self, q, kappa):
6165         kapinv = 1/kappa
6166         kappkapinv = kappa+kapinv
6167         return np.where(q <= kapinv/kappkapinv,
6168                         -np.log(q*kappkapinv*kappa)*kapinv,
6169                         np.log((1 - q)*kappkapinv/kappa)*kappa)
6170 
6171     def _stats(self, kappa):
6172         kapinv = 1/kappa
6173         mn = kapinv - kappa
6174         var = kapinv*kapinv + kappa*kappa
6175         g1 = 2.0*(1-np.power(kappa, 6))/np.power(1+np.power(kappa, 4), 1.5)
6176         g2 = 6.0*(1+np.power(kappa, 8))/np.power(1+np.power(kappa, 4), 2)
6177         return mn, var, g1, g2
6178 
6179     def _entropy(self, kappa):
6180         return 1 + np.log(kappa+1/kappa)
6181 
6182 
6183 laplace_asymmetric = laplace_asymmetric_gen(name='laplace_asymmetric')
6184 
6185 
6186 def _check_fit_input_parameters(dist, data, args, kwds):
6187     if not isinstance(data, CensoredData):
6188         data = np.asarray(data)
6189 
6190     floc = kwds.get('floc', None)
6191     fscale = kwds.get('fscale', None)
6192 
6193     num_shapes = len(dist.shapes.split(",")) if dist.shapes else 0
6194     fshape_keys = []
6195     fshapes = []
6196 
6197     # user has many options for fixing the shape, so here we standardize it
6198     # into 'f' + the number of the shape.
6199     # Adapted from `_reduce_func` in `_distn_infrastructure.py`:
6200     if dist.shapes:
6201         shapes = dist.shapes.replace(',', ' ').split()
6202         for j, s in enumerate(shapes):
6203             key = 'f' + str(j)
6204             names = [key, 'f' + s, 'fix_' + s]
6205             val = _get_fixed_fit_value(kwds, names)
6206             fshape_keys.append(key)
6207             fshapes.append(val)
6208             if val is not None:
6209                 kwds[key] = val
6210 
6211     # determine if there are any unknown arguments in kwds
6212     known_keys = {'loc', 'scale', 'optimizer', 'method',
6213                   'floc', 'fscale', *fshape_keys}
6214     unknown_keys = set(kwds).difference(known_keys)
6215     if unknown_keys:
6216         raise TypeError(f"Unknown keyword arguments: {unknown_keys}.")
6217 
6218     if len(args) > num_shapes:
6219         raise TypeError("Too many positional arguments.")
6220 
6221     if None not in {floc, fscale, *fshapes}:
6222         # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`.
6223         # Without this check, this function would just return the
6224         # parameters that were given.
6225         raise RuntimeError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to "
6226                            "optimize.")
6227 
6228     uncensored = data._uncensor() if isinstance(data, CensoredData) else data
6229     if not np.isfinite(uncensored).all():
6230         raise ValueError("The data contains non-finite values.")
6231 
6232     return (data, *fshapes, floc, fscale)
6233 
6234 
6235 class levy_gen(rv_continuous):
6236     r"""A Levy continuous random variable. 
6237  
6238     %(before_notes)s 
6239  
6240     See Also 
6241     -------- 
6242     levy_stable, levy_l 
6243  
6244     Notes 
6245     ----- 
6246     The probability density function for `levy` is: 
6247  
6248     .. math:: 
6249  
6250         f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi x^3}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2x}\right) 
6251  
6252     for :math:`x > 0`. 
6253  
6254     This is the same as the Levy-stable distribution with :math:`a=1/2` and 
6255     :math:`b=1`. 
6256  
6257     %(after_notes)s 
6258  
6259     Examples 
6260     -------- 
6261     >>> import numpy as np 
6262     >>> from scipy.stats import levy 
6263     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
6264     >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) 
6265  
6266     Calculate the first four moments: 
6267  
6268     >>> mean, var, skew, kurt = levy.stats(moments='mvsk') 
6269  
6270     Display the probability density function (``pdf``): 
6271  
6272     >>> # `levy` is very heavy-tailed. 
6273     >>> # To show a nice plot, let's cut off the upper 40 percent. 
6274     >>> a, b = levy.ppf(0), levy.ppf(0.6) 
6275     >>> x = np.linspace(a, b, 100) 
6276     >>> ax.plot(x, levy.pdf(x), 
6277     ...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='levy pdf') 
6278  
6279     Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) 
6280     to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a "frozen" 
6281     RV object holding the given parameters fixed. 
6282  
6283     Freeze the distribution and display the frozen ``pdf``: 
6284  
6285     >>> rv = levy() 
6286     >>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf') 
6287  
6288     Check accuracy of ``cdf`` and ``ppf``: 
6289  
6290     >>> vals = levy.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999]) 
6291     >>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], levy.cdf(vals)) 
6292     True 
6293  
6294     Generate random numbers: 
6295  
6296     >>> r = levy.rvs(size=1000) 
6297  
6298     And compare the histogram: 
6299  
6300     >>> # manual binning to ignore the tail 
6301     >>> bins = np.concatenate((np.linspace(a, b, 20), [np.max(r)])) 
6302     >>> ax.hist(r, bins=bins, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2) 
6303     >>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]]) 
6304     >>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False) 
6305     >>> plt.show() 
6306  
6307     """
6308     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
6309 
6310     def _shape_info(self):
6311         return []
6312 
6313     def _pdf(self, x):
6314         # levy.pdf(x) = 1 / (x * sqrt(2*pi*x)) * exp(-1/(2*x))
6315         return 1 / np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x) / x * np.exp(-1/(2*x))
6316 
6317     def _cdf(self, x):
6318         # Equivalent to 2*norm.sf(np.sqrt(1/x))
6319         return sc.erfc(np.sqrt(0.5 / x))
6320 
6321     def _sf(self, x):
6322         return sc.erf(np.sqrt(0.5 / x))
6323 
6324     def _ppf(self, q):
6325         # Equivalent to 1.0/(norm.isf(q/2)**2) or 0.5/(erfcinv(q)**2)
6326         val = _norm_isf(q/2)
6327         return 1.0 / (val * val)
6328 
6329     def _isf(self, p):
6330         return 1/(2*sc.erfinv(p)**2)
6331 
6332     def _stats(self):
6333         return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
6334 
6335 
6336 levy = levy_gen(a=0.0, name="levy")
6337 
6338 
6339 class levy_l_gen(rv_continuous):
6340     r"""A left-skewed Levy continuous random variable. 
6341  
6342     %(before_notes)s 
6343  
6344     See Also 
6345     -------- 
6346     levy, levy_stable 
6347  
6348     Notes 
6349     ----- 
6350     The probability density function for `levy_l` is: 
6351  
6352     .. math:: 
6353         f(x) = \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{2\pi |x|}} \exp{ \left(-\frac{1}{2|x|} \right)} 
6354  
6355     for :math:`x < 0`. 
6356  
6357     This is the same as the Levy-stable distribution with :math:`a=1/2` and 
6358     :math:`b=-1`. 
6359  
6360     %(after_notes)s 
6361  
6362     Examples 
6363     -------- 
6364     >>> import numpy as np 
6365     >>> from scipy.stats import levy_l 
6366     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
6367     >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) 
6368  
6369     Calculate the first four moments: 
6370  
6371     >>> mean, var, skew, kurt = levy_l.stats(moments='mvsk') 
6372  
6373     Display the probability density function (``pdf``): 
6374  
6375     >>> # `levy_l` is very heavy-tailed. 
6376     >>> # To show a nice plot, let's cut off the lower 40 percent. 
6377     >>> a, b = levy_l.ppf(0.4), levy_l.ppf(1) 
6378     >>> x = np.linspace(a, b, 100) 
6379     >>> ax.plot(x, levy_l.pdf(x), 
6380     ...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='levy_l pdf') 
6381  
6382     Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) 
6383     to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a "frozen" 
6384     RV object holding the given parameters fixed. 
6385  
6386     Freeze the distribution and display the frozen ``pdf``: 
6387  
6388     >>> rv = levy_l() 
6389     >>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf') 
6390  
6391     Check accuracy of ``cdf`` and ``ppf``: 
6392  
6393     >>> vals = levy_l.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999]) 
6394     >>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], levy_l.cdf(vals)) 
6395     True 
6396  
6397     Generate random numbers: 
6398  
6399     >>> r = levy_l.rvs(size=1000) 
6400  
6401     And compare the histogram: 
6402  
6403     >>> # manual binning to ignore the tail 
6404     >>> bins = np.concatenate(([np.min(r)], np.linspace(a, b, 20))) 
6405     >>> ax.hist(r, bins=bins, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2) 
6406     >>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]]) 
6407     >>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False) 
6408     >>> plt.show() 
6409  
6410     """
6411     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
6412 
6413     def _shape_info(self):
6414         return []
6415 
6416     def _pdf(self, x):
6417         # levy_l.pdf(x) = 1 / (abs(x) * sqrt(2*pi*abs(x))) * exp(-1/(2*abs(x)))
6418         ax = abs(x)
6419         return 1/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*ax)/ax*np.exp(-1/(2*ax))
6420 
6421     def _cdf(self, x):
6422         ax = abs(x)
6423         return 2 * _norm_cdf(1 / np.sqrt(ax)) - 1
6424 
6425     def _sf(self, x):
6426         ax = abs(x)
6427         return 2 * _norm_sf(1 / np.sqrt(ax))
6428 
6429     def _ppf(self, q):
6430         val = _norm_ppf((q + 1.0) / 2)
6431         return -1.0 / (val * val)
6432 
6433     def _isf(self, p):
6434         return -1/_norm_isf(p/2)**2
6435 
6436     def _stats(self):
6437         return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan
6438 
6439 
6440 levy_l = levy_l_gen(b=0.0, name="levy_l")
6441 
6442 
6443 class logistic_gen(rv_continuous):
6444     r"""A logistic (or Sech-squared) continuous random variable. 
6445  
6446     %(before_notes)s 
6447  
6448     Notes 
6449     ----- 
6450     The probability density function for `logistic` is: 
6451  
6452     .. math:: 
6453  
6454         f(x) = \frac{\exp(-x)} 
6455                     {(1+\exp(-x))^2} 
6456  
6457     `logistic` is a special case of `genlogistic` with ``c=1``. 
6458  
6459     Remark that the survival function (``logistic.sf``) is equal to the 
6460     Fermi-Dirac distribution describing fermionic statistics. 
6461  
6462     %(after_notes)s 
6463  
6464     %(example)s 
6465  
6466     """
6467     def _shape_info(self):
6468         return []
6469 
6470     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
6471         return random_state.logistic(size=size)
6472 
6473     def _pdf(self, x):
6474         # logistic.pdf(x) = exp(-x) / (1+exp(-x))**2
6475         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x))
6476 
6477     def _logpdf(self, x):
6478         y = -np.abs(x)
6479         return y - 2. * sc.log1p(np.exp(y))
6480 
6481     def _cdf(self, x):
6482         return sc.expit(x)
6483 
6484     def _logcdf(self, x):
6485         return sc.log_expit(x)
6486 
6487     def _ppf(self, q):
6488         return sc.logit(q)
6489 
6490     def _sf(self, x):
6491         return sc.expit(-x)
6492 
6493     def _logsf(self, x):
6494         return sc.log_expit(-x)
6495 
6496     def _isf(self, q):
6497         return -sc.logit(q)
6498 
6499     def _stats(self):
6500         return 0, np.pi*np.pi/3.0, 0, 6.0/5.0
6501 
6502     def _entropy(self):
6503         # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution
6504         return 2.0
6505 
6506     @_call_super_mom
6507     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
6508     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
6509         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
6510             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
6511 
6512         data, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
6513                                                          args, kwds)
6514         n = len(data)
6515 
6516         # rv_continuous provided guesses
6517         loc, scale = self._fitstart(data)
6518         # these are trumped by user-provided guesses
6519         loc, scale = kwds.get('loc', loc), kwds.get('scale', scale)
6520 
6521         # the maximum likelihood estimators `a` and `b` of the location and
6522         # scale parameters are roots of the two equations described in `func`.
6523         # Source: Statistical Distributions, 3rd Edition. Evans, Hastings, and
6524         # Peacock (2000), Page 130
6525 
6526         def dl_dloc(loc, scale=fscale):
6527             c = (data - loc) / scale
6528             return np.sum(sc.expit(c)) - n/2
6529 
6530         def dl_dscale(scale, loc=floc):
6531             c = (data - loc) / scale
6532             return np.sum(c*np.tanh(c/2)) - n
6533 
6534         def func(params):
6535             loc, scale = params
6536             return dl_dloc(loc, scale), dl_dscale(scale, loc)
6537 
6538         if fscale is not None and floc is None:
6539             res = optimize.root(dl_dloc, (loc,))
6540             loc = res.x[0]
6541             scale = fscale
6542         elif floc is not None and fscale is None:
6543             res = optimize.root(dl_dscale, (scale,))
6544             scale = res.x[0]
6545             loc = floc
6546         else:
6547             res = optimize.root(func, (loc, scale))
6548             loc, scale = res.x
6549 
6550         # Note: gh-18176 reported data for which the reported MLE had
6551         # `scale < 0`. To fix the bug, we return abs(scale). This is OK because
6552         # `dl_dscale` and `dl_dloc` are even and odd functions of `scale`,
6553         # respectively, so if `-scale` is a solution, so is `scale`.
6554         scale = abs(scale)
6555         return ((loc, scale) if res.success
6556                 else super().fit(data, *args, **kwds))
6557 
6558 
6559 logistic = logistic_gen(name='logistic')
6560 
6561 
6562 class loggamma_gen(rv_continuous):
6563     r"""A log gamma continuous random variable. 
6564  
6565     %(before_notes)s 
6566  
6567     Notes 
6568     ----- 
6569     The probability density function for `loggamma` is: 
6570  
6571     .. math:: 
6572  
6573         f(x, c) = \frac{\exp(c x - \exp(x))} 
6574                        {\Gamma(c)} 
6575  
6576     for all :math:`x, c > 0`. Here, :math:`\Gamma` is the 
6577     gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 
6578  
6579     `loggamma` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 
6580  
6581     %(after_notes)s 
6582  
6583     %(example)s 
6584  
6585     """
6586 
6587     def _shape_info(self):
6588         return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
6589 
6590     def _rvs(self, c, size=None, random_state=None):
6591         # Use the property of the gamma distribution Gamma(c)
6592         #    Gamma(c) ~ Gamma(c + 1)*U**(1/c),
6593         # where U is uniform on [0, 1]. (See, e.g.,
6594         # G. Marsaglia and W.W. Tsang, "A simple method for generating gamma
6595         # variables", https://doi.org/10.1145/358407.358414)
6596         # So
6597         #    log(Gamma(c)) ~ log(Gamma(c + 1)) + log(U)/c
6598         # Generating a sample with this formulation is a bit slower
6599         # than the more obvious log(Gamma(c)), but it avoids loss
6600         # of precision when c << 1.
6601         return (np.log(random_state.gamma(c + 1, size=size))
6602                 + np.log(random_state.uniform(size=size))/c)
6603 
6604     def _pdf(self, x, c):
6605         # loggamma.pdf(x, c) = exp(c*x-exp(x)) / gamma(c)
6606         return np.exp(c*x-np.exp(x)-sc.gammaln(c))
6607 
6608     def _logpdf(self, x, c):
6609         return c*x - np.exp(x) - sc.gammaln(c)
6610 
6611     def _cdf(self, x, c):
6612         # This function is gammainc(c, exp(x)), where gammainc(c, z) is
6613         # the regularized incomplete gamma function.
6614         # The first term in a series expansion of gamminc(c, z) is
6615         # z**c/Gamma(c+1); see 6.5.29 of Abramowitz & Stegun (and refer
6616         # back to 6.5.1, 6.5.2 and 6.5.4 for the relevant notation).
6617         # This can also be found in the wikipedia article
6618         # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incomplete_gamma_function.
6619         # Here we use that formula when x is sufficiently negative that
6620         # exp(x) will result in subnormal numbers and lose precision.
6621         # We evaluate the log of the expression first to allow the possible
6622         # cancellation of the terms in the division, and then exponentiate.
6623         # That is,
6624         #     exp(x)**c/Gamma(c+1) = exp(log(exp(x)**c/Gamma(c+1)))
6625         #                          = exp(c*x - gammaln(c+1))
6626         return _lazywhere(x < _LOGXMIN, (x, c),
6627                           lambda x, c: np.exp(c*x - sc.gammaln(c+1)),
6628                           f2=lambda x, c: sc.gammainc(c, np.exp(x)))
6629 
6630     def _ppf(self, q, c):
6631         # The expression used when g < _XMIN inverts the one term expansion
6632         # given in the comments of _cdf().
6633         g = sc.gammaincinv(c, q)
6634         return _lazywhere(g < _XMIN, (g, q, c),
6635                           lambda g, q, c: (np.log(q) + sc.gammaln(c+1))/c,
6636                           f2=lambda g, q, c: np.log(g))
6637 
6638     def _sf(self, x, c):
6639         # See the comments for _cdf() for how x < _LOGXMIN is handled.
6640         return _lazywhere(x < _LOGXMIN, (x, c),
6641                           lambda x, c: -np.expm1(c*x - sc.gammaln(c+1)),
6642                           f2=lambda x, c: sc.gammaincc(c, np.exp(x)))
6643 
6644     def _isf(self, q, c):
6645         # The expression used when g < _XMIN inverts the complement of
6646         # the one term expansion given in the comments of _cdf().
6647         g = sc.gammainccinv(c, q)
6648         return _lazywhere(g < _XMIN, (g, q, c),
6649                           lambda g, q, c: (np.log1p(-q) + sc.gammaln(c+1))/c,
6650                           f2=lambda g, q, c: np.log(g))
6651 
6652     def _stats(self, c):
