10708 
10709             # Unscaled, translated values should be positive when the location
10710             # is fixed. If it is not the case, we end up with negative `scale`
10711             # and `c`, which would trigger a FitError before exiting the
10712             # method.
10713             if floc is not None and data.min() - floc < 0:
10714                 raise FitDataError("truncpareto", lower=1, upper=c)
10715 
10716             # Standardised values should be within the distribution support
10717             # when all parameters controlling it are fixed. If it not the case,
10718             # `fc` is overridden by `c` determined from `floc` and `fscale` when
10719             # raising the exception.
10720             if fc and (floc is not None) and fscale:
10721                 if data.max() > fc*fscale + floc:
10722                     raise FitDataError("truncpareto", lower=1,
10723                                        upper=get_c(loc, scale))
10724 
10725             # The other constraints should be automatically satisfied
10726             # from the analytical expressions of the parameters.
10727             # If fc or fscale are respectively less than one or less than 0,
10728             # a FitError is triggered before exiting the method.
10729 
10730             if fb is None:
10731                 std_data = (data - loc)/scale
10732                 logm = log_mean(std_data)
10733                 logc = np.log(c)
10734                 # Condition for a positive root to exist.
10735                 if not (2*logm < logc):
10736                     return fallback(data, *args, **kwds)
10737 
10738                 lbrack = 1/logm + 1/(logm - logc)
10739                 rbrack = np.nextafter(1/logm, 0)
10740                 try:
10741                     res = root_scalar(dL_dB, (logc, logm),
10742                                       bracket=(lbrack, rbrack))
10743                     # we should then never get there
10744                     if not res.converged:
10745                         return fallback(data, *args, **kwds)
10746                     b = res.root
10747                 except ValueError:
10748                     b = rbrack
10749             else:
10750                 b = fb
10751 
10752         # The distribution requires that `scale+loc <= data <= c*scale+loc`.
10753         # To avoid numerical issues, some tuning may be necessary.
10754         # We adjust `scale` to satisfy the lower bound, and we adjust
10755         # `c` to satisfy the upper bound.
10756         if not (scale+loc) < mn:
10757             if fscale:
10758                 loc = np.nextafter(loc, -np.inf)
10759             else:
10760                 scale = get_scale(loc)
10761                 scale = np.nextafter(scale, 0)
10762         if not (c*scale+loc) > mx:
10763             c = get_c(loc, scale)
10764             c = np.nextafter(c, np.inf)
10765 
10766         if not (np.all(self._argcheck(b, c)) and (scale > 0)):
10767             return fallback(data, *args, **kwds)
10768 
10769         params_override = b, c, loc, scale
10770         if floc is None and fscale is None:
10771             # Based on testing in gh-16782, the following methods are only
10772             # reliable if either `floc` or `fscale` are provided. They are
10773             # fast, though, so might as well see if they are better than the
10774             # generic method.
10775             params_super = fallback(data, *args, **kwds)
10776             nllf_override = self.nnlf(params_override, data)
10777             nllf_super = self.nnlf(params_super, data)
10778             if nllf_super < nllf_override:
10779                 return params_super
10780 
10781         return params_override
10782 
10783 
10784 truncpareto = truncpareto_gen(a=1.0, name='truncpareto')
10785 truncpareto._support = (1.0, 'c')
10786 
10787 
10788 class tukeylambda_gen(rv_continuous):
10789     r"""A Tukey-Lamdba continuous random variable. 
10790  
10791     %(before_notes)s 
10792  
10793     Notes 
10794     ----- 
10795     A flexible distribution, able to represent and interpolate between the 
10796     following distributions: 
10797  
10798     - Cauchy                (:math:`lambda = -1`) 
10799     - logistic              (:math:`lambda = 0`) 
10800     - approx Normal         (:math:`lambda = 0.14`) 
10801     - uniform from -1 to 1  (:math:`lambda = 1`) 
10802  
10803     `tukeylambda` takes a real number :math:`lambda` (denoted ``lam`` 
10804     in the implementation) as a shape parameter. 
10805  
10806     %(after_notes)s 
10807  
10808     %(example)s 
10809  
10810     """
10811     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
10812 
10813     def _argcheck(self, lam):
10814         return np.isfinite(lam)
10815 
10816     def _shape_info(self):
10817         return [_ShapeInfo("lam", False, (-np.inf, np.inf), (False, False))]
10818 
10819     def _get_support(self, lam):
10820         b = _lazywhere(lam > 0, (lam,),
10821                        f=lambda lam: 1/lam,
10822                        fillvalue=np.inf)
10823         return -b, b
10824 
10825     def _pdf(self, x, lam):
10826         Fx = np.asarray(sc.tklmbda(x, lam))
10827         Px = Fx**(lam-1.0) + (np.asarray(1-Fx))**(lam-1.0)
10828         with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
10829             Px = 1.0/np.asarray(Px)
10830             return np.where((lam <= 0) | (abs(x) < 1.0/np.asarray(lam)), Px, 0.0)
10831 
10832     def _cdf(self, x, lam):
10833         return sc.tklmbda(x, lam)
10834 
10835     def _ppf(self, q, lam):
10836         return sc.boxcox(q, lam) - sc.boxcox1p(-q, lam)
10837 
10838     def _stats(self, lam):
10839         return 0, _tlvar(lam), 0, _tlkurt(lam)
10840 
10841     def _entropy(self, lam):
10842         def integ(p):
10843             return np.log(pow(p, lam-1)+pow(1-p, lam-1))
10844         return integrate.quad(integ, 0, 1)[0]
10845 
10846 
10847 tukeylambda = tukeylambda_gen(name='tukeylambda')
10848 
10849 
10850 class FitUniformFixedScaleDataError(FitDataError):
10851     def __init__(self, ptp, fscale):
10852         self.args = (
10853             "Invalid values in `data`.  Maximum likelihood estimation with "
10854             "the uniform distribution and fixed scale requires that "
10855             f"np.ptp(data) <= fscale, but np.ptp(data) = {ptp} and "
10856             f"fscale = {fscale}."
10857         )
10858 
10859 
10860 class uniform_gen(rv_continuous):
10861     r"""A uniform continuous random variable. 
10862  
10863     In the standard form, the distribution is uniform on ``[0, 1]``. Using 
10864     the parameters ``loc`` and ``scale``, one obtains the uniform distribution 
10865     on ``[loc, loc + scale]``. 
10866  
10867     %(before_notes)s 
10868  
10869     %(example)s 
10870  
10871     """
10872     def _shape_info(self):
10873         return []
10874 
10875     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
10876         return random_state.uniform(0.0, 1.0, size)
10877 
10878     def _pdf(self, x):
10879         return 1.0*(x == x)
10880 
10881     def _cdf(self, x):
10882         return x
10883 
10884     def _ppf(self, q):
10885         return q
10886 
10887     def _stats(self):
10888         return 0.5, 1.0/12, 0, -1.2
10889 
10890     def _entropy(self):
10891         return 0.0
10892 
10893     @_call_super_mom
10894     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
10895         """ 
10896         Maximum likelihood estimate for the location and scale parameters. 
10897  
10898         `uniform.fit` uses only the following parameters.  Because exact 
10899         formulas are used, the parameters related to optimization that are 
10900         available in the `fit` method of other distributions are ignored 
10901         here.  The only positional argument accepted is `data`. 
10902  
10903         Parameters 
10904         ---------- 
10905         data : array_like 
10906             Data to use in calculating the maximum likelihood estimate. 
10907         floc : float, optional 
10908             Hold the location parameter fixed to the specified value. 
10909         fscale : float, optional 
10910             Hold the scale parameter fixed to the specified value. 
10911  
10912         Returns 
10913         ------- 
10914         loc, scale : float 
10915             Maximum likelihood estimates for the location and scale. 
10916  
10917         Notes 
10918         ----- 
10919         An error is raised if `floc` is given and any values in `data` are 
10920         less than `floc`, or if `fscale` is given and `fscale` is less 
10921         than ``data.max() - data.min()``.  An error is also raised if both 
10922         `floc` and `fscale` are given. 
10923  
10924         Examples 
10925         -------- 
10926         >>> import numpy as np 
10927         >>> from scipy.stats import uniform 
10928  
10929         We'll fit the uniform distribution to `x`: 
10930  
10931         >>> x = np.array([2, 2.5, 3.1, 9.5, 13.0]) 
10932  
10933         For a uniform distribution MLE, the location is the minimum of the 
10934         data, and the scale is the maximum minus the minimum. 
10935  
10936         >>> loc, scale = uniform.fit(x) 
10937         >>> loc 
10938         2.0 
10939         >>> scale 
10940         11.0 
10941  
10942         If we know the data comes from a uniform distribution where the support 
10943         starts at 0, we can use ``floc=0``: 
10944  
10945         >>> loc, scale = uniform.fit(x, floc=0) 
10946         >>> loc 
10947         0.0 
10948         >>> scale 
10949         13.0 
10950  
10951         Alternatively, if we know the length of the support is 12, we can use 
10952         ``fscale=12``: 
10953  
10954         >>> loc, scale = uniform.fit(x, fscale=12) 
10955         >>> loc 
10956         1.5 
10957         >>> scale 
10958         12.0 
10959  
10960         In that last example, the support interval is [1.5, 13.5].  This 
10961         solution is not unique.  For example, the distribution with ``loc=2`` 
10962         and ``scale=12`` has the same likelihood as the one above.  When 
10963         `fscale` is given and it is larger than ``data.max() - data.min()``, 
10964         the parameters returned by the `fit` method center the support over 
10965         the interval ``[data.min(), data.max()]``. 
10966  
10967         """
10968         if len(args) > 0:
10969             raise TypeError("Too many arguments.")
10970 
10971         floc = kwds.pop('floc', None)
10972         fscale = kwds.pop('fscale', None)
10973 
10974         _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds)
10975 
10976         if floc is not None and fscale is not None:
10977             # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`.
10978             raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to "
10979                              "optimize.")
10980 
10981         data = np.asarray(data)
10982 
10983         if not np.isfinite(data).all():
10984             raise ValueError("The data contains non-finite values.")
10985 
10986         # MLE for the uniform distribution
10987         # --------------------------------
10988         # The PDF is
10989         #
10990         #     f(x, loc, scale) = {1/scale  for loc <= x <= loc + scale
10991         #                        {0        otherwise}
10992         #
10993         # The likelihood function is
10994         #     L(x, loc, scale) = (1/scale)**n
10995         # where n is len(x), assuming loc <= x <= loc + scale for all x.
10996         # The log-likelihood is
10997         #     l(x, loc, scale) = -n*log(scale)
10998         # The log-likelihood is maximized by making scale as small as possible,
10999         # while keeping loc <= x <= loc + scale.   So if neither loc nor scale
11000         # are fixed, the log-likelihood is maximized by choosing
11001         #     loc = x.min()
11002         #     scale = np.ptp(x)
11003         # If loc is fixed, it must be less than or equal to x.min(), and then
11004         # the scale is
11005         #     scale = x.max() - loc
11006         # If scale is fixed, it must not be less than np.ptp(x).  If scale is
11007         # greater than np.ptp(x), the solution is not unique.  Note that the
11008         # likelihood does not depend on loc, except for the requirement that
11009         # loc <= x <= loc + scale.  All choices of loc for which
11010         #     x.max() - scale <= loc <= x.min()
11011         # have the same log-likelihood.  In this case, we choose loc such that
11012         # the support is centered over the interval [data.min(), data.max()]:
11013         #     loc = x.min() = 0.5*(scale - np.ptp(x))
11014 
11015         if fscale is None:
11016             # scale is not fixed.
11017             if floc is None:
11018                 # loc is not fixed, scale is not fixed.
11019                 loc = data.min()
11020                 scale = np.ptp(data)
11021             else:
11022                 # loc is fixed, scale is not fixed.
11023                 loc = floc
11024                 scale = data.max() - loc
11025                 if data.min() < loc:
11026                     raise FitDataError("uniform", lower=loc, upper=loc + scale)
11027         else:
11028             # loc is not fixed, scale is fixed.
11029             ptp = np.ptp(data)
11030             if ptp > fscale:
11031                 raise FitUniformFixedScaleDataError(ptp=ptp, fscale=fscale)
11032             # If ptp < fscale, the ML estimate is not unique; see the comments
11033             # above.  We choose the distribution for which the support is
11034             # centered over the interval [data.min(), data.max()].
11035             loc = data.min() - 0.5*(fscale - ptp)
11036             scale = fscale
11037 
11038         # We expect the return values to be floating point, so ensure it
11039         # by explicitly converting to float.
11040         return float(loc), float(scale)
11041 
11042 
11043 uniform = uniform_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='uniform')
11044 
11045 
11046 class vonmises_gen(rv_continuous):
11047     r"""A Von Mises continuous random variable. 
11048  
11049     %(before_notes)s 
11050  
11051     See Also 
11052     -------- 
11053     scipy.stats.vonmises_fisher : Von-Mises Fisher distribution on a 
11054                                   hypersphere 
11055  
11056     Notes 
11057     ----- 
11058     The probability density function for `vonmises` and `vonmises_line` is: 
11059  
11060     .. math:: 
11061  
11062         f(x, \kappa) = \frac{ \exp(\kappa \cos(x)) }{ 2 \pi I_0(\kappa) } 
11063  
11064     for :math:`-\pi \le x \le \pi`, :math:`\kappa \ge 0`. :math:`I_0` is the 
11065     modified Bessel function of order zero (`scipy.special.i0`). 
11066  
11067     `vonmises` is a circular distribution which does not restrict the 
11068     distribution to a fixed interval. Currently, there is no circular 
11069     distribution framework in SciPy. The ``cdf`` is implemented such that 
11070     ``cdf(x + 2*np.pi) == cdf(x) + 1``. 
11071  
11072     `vonmises_line` is the same distribution, defined on :math:`[-\pi, \pi]` 
11073     on the real line. This is a regular (i.e. non-circular) distribution. 
11074  
11075     Note about distribution parameters: `vonmises` and `vonmises_line` take 
11076     ``kappa`` as a shape parameter (concentration) and ``loc`` as the location 
11077     (circular mean). A ``scale`` parameter is accepted but does not have any 
11078     effect. 
11079  
11080     Examples 
11081     -------- 
11082     Import the necessary modules. 
11083  
11084     >>> import numpy as np 
11085     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
11086     >>> from scipy.stats import vonmises 
11087  
11088     Define distribution parameters. 
11089  
11090     >>> loc = 0.5 * np.pi  # circular mean 
11091     >>> kappa = 1  # concentration 
11092  
11093     Compute the probability density at ``x=0`` via the ``pdf`` method. 
11094  
11095     >>> vonmises.pdf(0, loc=loc, kappa=kappa) 
11096     0.12570826359722018 
11097  
11098     Verify that the percentile function ``ppf`` inverts the cumulative 
11099     distribution function ``cdf`` up to floating point accuracy. 
11100  
11101     >>> x = 1 
11102     >>> cdf_value = vonmises.cdf(x, loc=loc, kappa=kappa) 
11103     >>> ppf_value = vonmises.ppf(cdf_value, loc=loc, kappa=kappa) 
11104     >>> x, cdf_value, ppf_value 
11105     (1, 0.31489339900904967, 1.0000000000000004) 
11106  
11107     Draw 1000 random variates by calling the ``rvs`` method. 
11108  
11109     >>> sample_size = 1000 
11110     >>> sample = vonmises(loc=loc, kappa=kappa).rvs(sample_size) 
11111  
11112     Plot the von Mises density on a Cartesian and polar grid to emphasize 
11113     that it is a circular distribution. 
11114  
11115     >>> fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6)) 
11116     >>> left = plt.subplot(121) 
11117     >>> right = plt.subplot(122, projection='polar') 
11118     >>> x = np.linspace(-np.pi, np.pi, 500) 
11119     >>> vonmises_pdf = vonmises.pdf(x, loc=loc, kappa=kappa) 
11120     >>> ticks = [0, 0.15, 0.3] 
11121  
11122     The left image contains the Cartesian plot. 
11123  
11124     >>> left.plot(x, vonmises_pdf) 
11125     >>> left.set_yticks(ticks) 
11126     >>> number_of_bins = int(np.sqrt(sample_size)) 
11127     >>> left.hist(sample, density=True, bins=number_of_bins) 
11128     >>> left.set_title("Cartesian plot") 
11129     >>> left.set_xlim(-np.pi, np.pi) 
11130     >>> left.grid(True) 
11131  
11132     The right image contains the polar plot. 
11133  
11134     >>> right.plot(x, vonmises_pdf, label="PDF") 
11135     >>> right.set_yticks(ticks) 
11136     >>> right.hist(sample, density=True, bins=number_of_bins, 
11137     ...            label="Histogram") 
11138     >>> right.set_title("Polar plot") 
11139     >>> right.legend(bbox_to_anchor=(0.15, 1.06)) 
11140  
11141     """
11142     def _shape_info(self):
11143         return [_ShapeInfo("kappa", False, (0, np.inf), (True, False))]
11144 
11145     def _argcheck(self, kappa):
11146         return kappa >= 0
11147 
11148     def _rvs(self, kappa, size=None, random_state=None):
11149         return random_state.vonmises(0.0, kappa, size=size)
11150 
11151     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
11152     def rvs(self, *args, **kwds):
11153         rvs = super().rvs(*args, **kwds)
11154         return np.mod(rvs + np.pi, 2*np.pi) - np.pi
11155 
11156     def _pdf(self, x, kappa):
11157         # vonmises.pdf(x, kappa) = exp(kappa * cos(x)) / (2*pi*I[0](kappa))
11158         #                        = exp(kappa * (cos(x) - 1)) /
11159         #                          (2*pi*exp(-kappa)*I[0](kappa))
11160         #                        = exp(kappa * cosm1(x)) / (2*pi*i0e(kappa))
11161         return np.exp(kappa*sc.cosm1(x)) / (2*np.pi*sc.i0e(kappa))
11162 
11163     def _logpdf(self, x, kappa):
11164         # vonmises.pdf(x, kappa) = exp(kappa * cosm1(x)) / (2*pi*i0e(kappa))
11165         return kappa * sc.cosm1(x) - np.log(2*np.pi) - np.log(sc.i0e(kappa))
11166 
11167     def _cdf(self, x, kappa):
11168         return _stats.von_mises_cdf(kappa, x)
11169 
11170     def _stats_skip(self, kappa):
11171         return 0, None, 0, None
11172 
11173     def _entropy(self, kappa):
11174         # vonmises.entropy(kappa) = -kappa * I[1](kappa) / I[0](kappa) +
11175         #                           log(2 * np.pi * I[0](kappa))
11176         #                         = -kappa * I[1](kappa) * exp(-kappa) /
11177         #                           (I[0](kappa) * exp(-kappa)) +
11178         #                           log(2 * np.pi *
11179         #                           I[0](kappa) * exp(-kappa) / exp(-kappa))
11180         #                         = -kappa * sc.i1e(kappa) / sc.i0e(kappa) +
11181         #                           log(2 * np.pi * i0e(kappa)) + kappa
11182         return (-kappa * sc.i1e(kappa) / sc.i0e(kappa) +
11183                 np.log(2 * np.pi * sc.i0e(kappa)) + kappa)
11184 
11185     @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 
11186         The default limits of integration are endpoints of the interval 
11187         of width ``2*pi`` centered at `loc` (e.g. ``[-pi, pi]`` when 
11188         ``loc=0``).\n\n""")
11189     def expect(self, func=None, args=(), loc=0, scale=1, lb=None, ub=None,
11190                conditional=False, **kwds):
11191         _a, _b = -np.pi, np.pi
11192 
11193         if lb is None:
11194             lb = loc + _a
11195         if ub is None:
11196             ub = loc + _b
11197 
11198         return super().expect(func, args, loc,
11199                               scale, lb, ub, conditional, **kwds)
11200 
11201     @_call_super_mom
11202     @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 
11203         Fit data is assumed to represent angles and will be wrapped onto the 
11204         unit circle. `f0` and `fscale` are ignored; the returned shape is 
11205         always the maximum likelihood estimate and the scale is always 
11206         1. Initial guesses are ignored.\n\n""")
11207     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
11208         if kwds.pop('superfit', False):
11209             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
11210 
11211         data, fshape, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(self, data,
11212                                                                  args, kwds)
11213         if self.a == -np.pi:
11214             # vonmises line case, here the default fit method will be used
11215             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
11216 
11217         # wrap data to interval [0, 2*pi]
11218         data = np.mod(data, 2 * np.pi)
11219 
11220         def find_mu(data):
11221             return stats.circmean(data)
11222 
11223         def find_kappa(data, loc):
11224             # Usually, sources list the following as the equation to solve for
11225             # the MLE of the shape parameter:
11226             # r = I[1](kappa)/I[0](kappa), where r = mean resultant length
11227             # This is valid when the location is the MLE of location.
11228             # More generally, when the location may be fixed at an arbitrary
11229             # value, r should be defined as follows:
11230             r = np.sum(np.cos(loc - data))/len(data)
11231             # See gh-18128 for more information.
11232 
11233             # The function r[0](kappa) := I[1](kappa)/I[0](kappa) is monotonic
11234             # increasing from r[0](0) = 0 to r[0](+inf) = 1.  The partial
11235             # derivative of the log likelihood function with respect to kappa
11236             # is monotonic decreasing in kappa.
11237             if r == 1:
11238                 # All observations are (almost) equal to the mean.  Return
11239                 # some large kappa such that r[0](kappa) = 1.0 numerically.
11240                 return 1e16
11241             elif r > 0:
11242                 def solve_for_kappa(kappa):
11243                     return sc.i1e(kappa)/sc.i0e(kappa) - r
11244 
11245                 # The bounds of the root of r[0](kappa) = r are derived from
11246                 # selected bounds of r[0](x) given in [1, Eq. 11 & 16].  See
11247                 # gh-20102 for details.
11248                 #
11249                 # [1] Amos, D. E. (1973).  Computation of Modified Bessel
11250                 #     Functions and Their Ratios.  Mathematics of Computation,
11251                 #     28(125): 239-251.
11252                 lower_bound = r/(1-r)/(1+r)
11253                 upper_bound = 2*lower_bound
11254 
11255                 # The bounds are violated numerically for certain values of r,
11256                 # where solve_for_kappa evaluated at the bounds have the same
11257                 # sign.  This indicates numerical imprecision of i1e()/i0e().
11258                 # Return the violated bound in this case as it's more accurate.
11259                 if solve_for_kappa(lower_bound) >= 0:
11260                     return lower_bound
11261                 elif solve_for_kappa(upper_bound) <= 0:
11262                     return upper_bound
11263                 else:
11264                     root_res = root_scalar(solve_for_kappa, method="brentq",
11265                                            bracket=(lower_bound, upper_bound))
11266                     return root_res.root
11267             else:
11268                 # if the provided floc is very far from the circular mean,
11269                 # the mean resultant length r can become negative.
11270                 # In that case, the equation
11271                 # I[1](kappa)/I[0](kappa) = r does not have a solution.
11272                 # The maximum likelihood kappa is then 0 which practically
11273                 # results in the uniform distribution on the circle. As
11274                 # vonmises is defined for kappa > 0, return instead the
11275                 # smallest floating point value.
11276                 # See gh-18190 for more information
11277                 return np.finfo(float).tiny
11278 
11279         # location likelihood equation has a solution independent of kappa
11280         loc = floc if floc is not None else find_mu(data)
11281         # shape likelihood equation depends on location
11282         shape = fshape if fshape is not None else find_kappa(data, loc)
11283 
11284         loc = np.mod(loc + np.pi, 2 * np.pi) - np.pi  # ensure in [-pi, pi]
11285         return shape, loc, 1  # scale is not handled
11286 
11287 
11288 vonmises = vonmises_gen(name='vonmises')
11289 vonmises_line = vonmises_gen(a=-np.pi, b=np.pi, name='vonmises_line')
11290 
11291 
11292 class wald_gen(invgauss_gen):
11293     r"""A Wald continuous random variable. 
11294  
11295     %(before_notes)s 
11296  
11297     Notes 
11298     ----- 
11299     The probability density function for `wald` is: 
11300  
11301     .. math:: 
11302  
11303         f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi x^3}} \exp(- \frac{ (x-1)^2 }{ 2x }) 
11304  
11305     for :math:`x >= 0`. 
11306  
11307     `wald` is a special case of `invgauss` with ``mu=1``. 
11308  
11309     %(after_notes)s 
11310  
11311     %(example)s 
11312     """
11313     _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask
11314 
11315     def _shape_info(self):
11316         return []
11317 
11318     def _rvs(self, size=None, random_state=None):
11319         return random_state.wald(1.0, 1.0, size=size)
11320 
11321     def _pdf(self, x):
11322         # wald.pdf(x) = 1/sqrt(2*pi*x**3) * exp(-(x-1)**2/(2*x))
11323         return invgauss._pdf(x, 1.0)
11324 
11325     def _cdf(self, x):
11326         return invgauss._cdf(x, 1.0)
11327 
11328     def _sf(self, x):
11329         return invgauss._sf(x, 1.0)
11330 
11331     def _ppf(self, x):
11332         return invgauss._ppf(x, 1.0)
11333 
11334     def _isf(self, x):
11335         return invgauss._isf(x, 1.0)
11336 
11337     def _logpdf(self, x):
11338         return invgauss._logpdf(x, 1.0)
11339 
11340     def _logcdf(self, x):
11341         return invgauss._logcdf(x, 1.0)
11342 
11343     def _logsf(self, x):
11344         return invgauss._logsf(x, 1.0)
11345 
11346     def _stats(self):
11347         return 1.0, 1.0, 3.0, 15.0
11348 
11349     def _entropy(self):
11350         return invgauss._entropy(1.0)
11351 
11352 
11353 wald = wald_gen(a=0.0, name="wald")
11354 
11355 
11356 class wrapcauchy_gen(rv_continuous):
11357     r"""A wrapped Cauchy continuous random variable. 
11358  
11359     %(before_notes)s 
11360  
11361     Notes 
11362     ----- 
11363     The probability density function for `wrapcauchy` is: 
11364  
11365     .. math:: 
11366  
11367         f(x, c) = \frac{1-c^2}{2\pi (1+c^2 - 2c \cos(x))} 
11368  
11369     for :math:`0 \le x \le 2\pi`, :math:`0 < c < 1`. 
11370  
11371     `wrapcauchy` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 
11372  
11373     %(after_notes)s 
11374  
11375     %(example)s 
11376  
11377     """
11378     def _argcheck(self, c):
11379         return (c > 0) & (c < 1)
11380 
11381     def _shape_info(self):
11382         return [_ShapeInfo("c", False, (0, 1), (False, False))]
11383 
11384     def _pdf(self, x, c):
11385         # wrapcauchy.pdf(x, c) = (1-c**2) / (2*pi*(1+c**2-2*c*cos(x)))
11386         return (1.0-c*c)/(2*np.pi*(1+c*c-2*c*np.cos(x)))
11387 
11388     def _cdf(self, x, c):
11389 
11390         def f1(x, cr):
11391             # CDF for 0 <= x < pi
11392             return 1/np.pi * np.arctan(cr*np.tan(x/2))
11393 
11394         def f2(x, cr):
11395             # CDF for pi <= x <= 2*pi
11396             return 1 - 1/np.pi * np.arctan(cr*np.tan((2*np.pi - x)/2))
11397 
11398         cr = (1 + c)/(1 - c)
11399         return _lazywhere(x < np.pi, (x, cr), f=f1, f2=f2)
11400 
11401     def _ppf(self, q, c):
11402         val = (1.0-c)/(1.0+c)
11403         rcq = 2*np.arctan(val*np.tan(np.pi*q))
11404         rcmq = 2*np.pi-2*np.arctan(val*np.tan(np.pi*(1-q)))
11405         return np.where(q < 1.0/2, rcq, rcmq)
11406 
11407     def _entropy(self, c):
11408         return np.log(2*np.pi*(1-c*c))
11409 
11410     def _fitstart(self, data):
11411         # Use 0.5 as the initial guess of the shape parameter.
11412         # For the location and scale, use the minimum and
11413         # peak-to-peak/(2*pi), respectively.
11414         if isinstance(data, CensoredData):
11415             data = data._uncensor()
11416         return 0.5, np.min(data), np.ptp(data)/(2*np.pi)
11417 
11418 
11419 wrapcauchy = wrapcauchy_gen(a=0.0, b=2*np.pi, name='wrapcauchy')
11420 
11421 
11422 class gennorm_gen(rv_continuous):
11423     r"""A generalized normal continuous random variable. 
11424  
11425     %(before_notes)s 
11426  
11427     See Also 
11428     -------- 
11429     laplace : Laplace distribution 
11430     norm : normal distribution 
11431  
11432     Notes 
11433     ----- 
11434     The probability density function for `gennorm` is [1]_: 
11435  
11436     .. math:: 
11437  
11438         f(x, \beta) = \frac{\beta}{2 \Gamma(1/\beta)} \exp(-|x|^\beta), 
11439  
11440     where :math:`x` is a real number, :math:`\beta > 0` and 
11441     :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 
11442  
11443     `gennorm` takes ``beta`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\beta`. 
11444     For :math:`\beta = 1`, it is identical to a Laplace distribution. 
11445     For :math:`\beta = 2`, it is identical to a normal distribution 
11446     (with ``scale=1/sqrt(2)``). 
11447  
11448     References 
11449     ---------- 
11450  
11451     .. [1] "Generalized normal distribution, Version 1", 
11452            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_normal_distribution#Version_1 
11453  
11454     .. [2] Nardon, Martina, and Paolo Pianca. "Simulation techniques for 
11455            generalized Gaussian densities." Journal of Statistical 
11456            Computation and Simulation 79.11 (2009): 1317-1329 
11457  
11458     .. [3] Wicklin, Rick. "Simulate data from a generalized Gaussian 
11459            distribution" in The DO Loop blog, September 21, 2016, 
11460            https://blogs.sas.com/content/iml/2016/09/21/simulate-generalized-gaussian-sas.html 
11461  
11462     %(example)s 
11463  
11464     """
11465     def _shape_info(self):
11466         return [_ShapeInfo("beta", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
11467 
11468     def _pdf(self, x, beta):
11469         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, beta))
11470 
11471     def _logpdf(self, x, beta):
11472         return np.log(0.5*beta) - sc.gammaln(1.0/beta) - abs(x)**beta
11473 
11474     def _cdf(self, x, beta):
11475         c = 0.5 * np.sign(x)
11476         # evaluating (.5 + c) first prevents numerical cancellation
11477         return (0.5 + c) - c * sc.gammaincc(1.0/beta, abs(x)**beta)
11478 
11479     def _ppf(self, x, beta):
11480         c = np.sign(x - 0.5)
11481         # evaluating (1. + c) first prevents numerical cancellation
11482         return c * sc.gammainccinv(1.0/beta, (1.0 + c) - 2.0*c*x)**(1.0/beta)
11483 
11484     def _sf(self, x, beta):
11485         return self._cdf(-x, beta)
11486 
11487     def _isf(self, x, beta):
11488         return -self._ppf(x, beta)
11489 
11490     def _stats(self, beta):
11491         c1, c3, c5 = sc.gammaln([1.0/beta, 3.0/beta, 5.0/beta])
11492         return 0., np.exp(c3 - c1), 0., np.exp(c5 + c1 - 2.0*c3) - 3.
11493 
11494     def _entropy(self, beta):
11495         return 1. / beta - np.log(.5 * beta) + sc.gammaln(1. / beta)
11496 
11497     def _rvs(self, beta, size=None, random_state=None):
11498         # see [2]_ for the algorithm
11499         # see [3]_ for reference implementation in SAS
11500         z = random_state.gamma(1/beta, size=size)
11501         y = z ** (1/beta)
11502         # convert y to array to ensure masking support
11503         y = np.asarray(y)
11504         mask = random_state.random(size=y.shape) < 0.5
11505         y[mask] = -y[mask]
11506         return y
11507 
11508 
11509 gennorm = gennorm_gen(name='gennorm')
11510 
11511 
11512 class halfgennorm_gen(rv_continuous):
11513     r"""The upper half of a generalized normal continuous random variable. 
11514  
11515     %(before_notes)s 
11516  
11517     See Also 
11518     -------- 
11519     gennorm : generalized normal distribution 
11520     expon : exponential distribution 
11521     halfnorm : half normal distribution 
11522  
11523     Notes 
11524     ----- 
11525     The probability density function for `halfgennorm` is: 
11526  
11527     .. math:: 
11528  
11529         f(x, \beta) = \frac{\beta}{\Gamma(1/\beta)} \exp(-|x|^\beta) 
11530  
11531     for :math:`x, \beta > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function 
11532     (`scipy.special.gamma`). 
11533  
11534     `halfgennorm` takes ``beta`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\beta`. 
11535     For :math:`\beta = 1`, it is identical to an exponential distribution. 
11536     For :math:`\beta = 2`, it is identical to a half normal distribution 
11537     (with ``scale=1/sqrt(2)``). 
11538  
11539     References 
11540     ---------- 
11541  
11542     .. [1] "Generalized normal distribution, Version 1", 
11543            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_normal_distribution#Version_1 
11544  
11545     %(example)s 
11546  
11547     """
11548     def _shape_info(self):
11549         return [_ShapeInfo("beta", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
11550 
11551     def _pdf(self, x, beta):
11552         #                                 beta
11553         # halfgennorm.pdf(x, beta) =  -------------  exp(-|x|**beta)
11554         #                             gamma(1/beta)
11555         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, beta))
11556 
11557     def _logpdf(self, x, beta):
11558         return np.log(beta) - sc.gammaln(1.0/beta) - x**beta
11559 
11560     def _cdf(self, x, beta):
11561         return sc.gammainc(1.0/beta, x**beta)
11562 
11563     def _ppf(self, x, beta):
11564         return sc.gammaincinv(1.0/beta, x)**(1.0/beta)
11565 
11566     def _sf(self, x, beta):
11567         return sc.gammaincc(1.0/beta, x**beta)
11568 
11569     def _isf(self, x, beta):
11570         return sc.gammainccinv(1.0/beta, x)**(1.0/beta)
11571 
11572     def _entropy(self, beta):
11573         return 1.0/beta - np.log(beta) + sc.gammaln(1.0/beta)
11574 
11575 
11576 halfgennorm = halfgennorm_gen(a=0, name='halfgennorm')
11577 
11578 
11579 class crystalball_gen(rv_continuous):
11580     r""" 
11581     Crystalball distribution 
11582  
11583     %(before_notes)s 
11584  
11585     Notes 
11586     ----- 
11587     The probability density function for `crystalball` is: 
11588  
11589     .. math:: 
11590  
11591         f(x, \beta, m) =  \begin{cases} 
11592                             N \exp(-x^2 / 2),  &\text{for } x > -\beta\\ 
11593                             N A (B - x)^{-m}  &\text{for } x \le -\beta 
11594                           \end{cases} 
11595  
11596     where :math:`A = (m / |\beta|)^m  \exp(-\beta^2 / 2)`, 
11597     :math:`B = m/|\beta| - |\beta|` and :math:`N` is a normalisation constant. 
11598  
11599     `crystalball` takes :math:`\beta > 0` and :math:`m > 1` as shape 
11600     parameters.  :math:`\beta` defines the point where the pdf changes 
11601     from a power-law to a Gaussian distribution.  :math:`m` is the power 
11602     of the power-law tail. 
11603  
11604     %(after_notes)s 
11605  
11606     .. versionadded:: 0.19.0 
11607  
11608     References 
11609     ---------- 
11610     .. [1] "Crystal Ball Function", 
11611            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_Ball_function 
11612  
11613     %(example)s 
11614     """
11615     def _argcheck(self, beta, m):
11616         """ 
11617         Shape parameter bounds are m > 1 and beta > 0. 
11618         """
11619         return (m > 1) & (beta > 0)
11620 
11621     def _shape_info(self):
11622         ibeta = _ShapeInfo("beta", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
11623         im = _ShapeInfo("m", False, (1, np.inf), (False, False))
11624         return [ibeta, im]
11625 
11626     def _fitstart(self, data):
11627         # Arbitrary, but the default m=1 is not valid
11628         return super()._fitstart(data, args=(1, 1.5))
11629 
11630     def _pdf(self, x, beta, m):
11631         """ 
11632         Return PDF of the crystalball function. 
11633  
11634                                             -- 
11635                                            | exp(-x**2 / 2),  for x > -beta 
11636         crystalball.pdf(x, beta, m) =  N * | 
11637                                            | A * (B - x)**(-m), for x <= -beta 
11638                                             -- 
11639         """
11640         N = 1.0 / (m/beta / (m-1) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) +
11641                    _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta))
11642 
11643         def rhs(x, beta, m):
11644             return np.exp(-x**2 / 2)
11645 
11646         def lhs(x, beta, m):
11647             return ((m/beta)**m * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) *
11648                     (m/beta - beta - x)**(-m))
11649 
11650         return N * _lazywhere(x > -beta, (x, beta, m), f=rhs, f2=lhs)
11651 
11652     def _logpdf(self, x, beta, m):
11653         """ 
11654         Return the log of the PDF of the crystalball function. 
11655         """
11656         N = 1.0 / (m/beta / (m-1) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) +
11657                    _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta))
11658 
11659         def rhs(x, beta, m):
11660             return -x**2/2
11661 
11662         def lhs(x, beta, m):
11663             return m*np.log(m/beta) - beta**2/2 - m*np.log(m/beta - beta - x)
11664 
11665         return np.log(N) + _lazywhere(x > -beta, (x, beta, m), f=rhs, f2=lhs)
11666 
11667     def _cdf(self, x, beta, m):
11668         """ 
11669         Return CDF of the crystalball function 
11670         """
11671         N = 1.0 / (m/beta / (m-1) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) +
11672                    _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta))
11673 
11674         def rhs(x, beta, m):
11675             return ((m/beta) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) / (m-1) +
11676                     _norm_pdf_C * (_norm_cdf(x) - _norm_cdf(-beta)))
11677 
11678         def lhs(x, beta, m):
11679             return ((m/beta)**m * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) *
11680                     (m/beta - beta - x)**(-m+1) / (m-1))
11681 
11682         return N * _lazywhere(x > -beta, (x, beta, m), f=rhs, f2=lhs)
11683 
11684     def _sf(self, x, beta, m):
11685         """ 
11686         Survival function of the crystalball distribution. 
11687         """
11688 
11689         def rhs(x, beta, m):
11690             # M is the same as 1/N used elsewhere.
11691             M = m/beta/(m - 1)*np.exp(-beta**2/2) + _norm_pdf_C*_norm_cdf(beta)
11692             return _norm_pdf_C*_norm_sf(x)/M
11693 
11694         def lhs(x, beta, m):
11695             # Default behavior is OK in the left tail of the SF.
11696             return 1 - self._cdf(x, beta, m)
11697 
11698         return _lazywhere(x > -beta, (x, beta, m), f=rhs, f2=lhs)
11699 
11700     def _ppf(self, p, beta, m):
11701         N = 1.0 / (m/beta / (m-1) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) +
11702                    _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta))
11703         pbeta = N * (m/beta) * np.exp(-beta**2/2) / (m - 1)
11704 
11705         def ppf_less(p, beta, m):
11706             eb2 = np.exp(-beta**2/2)
11707             C = (m/beta) * eb2 / (m-1)
11708             N = 1/(C + _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta))
11709             return (m/beta - beta -
11710                     ((m - 1)*(m/beta)**(-m)/eb2*p/N)**(1/(1-m)))
11711 
11712         def ppf_greater(p, beta, m):
11713             eb2 = np.exp(-beta**2/2)
11714             C = (m/beta) * eb2 / (m-1)
11715             N = 1/(C + _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta))
11716             return _norm_ppf(_norm_cdf(-beta) + (1/_norm_pdf_C)*(p/N - C))
11717 
11718         return _lazywhere(p < pbeta, (p, beta, m), f=ppf_less, f2=ppf_greater)
11719 
11720     def _munp(self, n, beta, m):
11721         """ 
11722         Returns the n-th non-central moment of the crystalball function. 
11723         """
11724         N = 1.0 / (m/beta / (m-1) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) +
11725                    _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta))
11726 
11727         def n_th_moment(n, beta, m):
11728             """ 
11729             Returns n-th moment. Defined only if n+1 < m 
11730             Function cannot broadcast due to the loop over n 
11731             """
11732             A = (m/beta)**m * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0)
11733             B = m/beta - beta
11734             rhs = (2**((n-1)/2.0) * sc.gamma((n+1)/2) *
11735                    (1.0 + (-1)**n * sc.gammainc((n+1)/2, beta**2 / 2)))
11736             lhs = np.zeros(rhs.shape)
11737             for k in range(int(n) + 1):
11738                 lhs += (sc.binom(n, k) * B**(n-k) * (-1)**k / (m - k - 1) *
11739                         (m/beta)**(-m + k + 1))
11740             return A * lhs + rhs
11741 
11742         return N * _lazywhere(n + 1 < m, (n, beta, m),
11743                               np.vectorize(n_th_moment, otypes=[np.float64]),
11744                               np.inf)
11745 
11746 
11747 crystalball = crystalball_gen(name='crystalball', longname="A Crystalball Function")
11748 
11749 
11750 def _argus_phi(chi):
11751     """ 
11752     Utility function for the argus distribution used in the pdf, sf and 
11753     moment calculation. 
11754     Note that for all x > 0: 
11755     gammainc(1.5, x**2/2) = 2 * (_norm_cdf(x) - x * _norm_pdf(x) - 0.5). 
11756     This can be verified directly by noting that the cdf of Gamma(1.5) can 
11757     be written as erf(sqrt(x)) - 2*sqrt(x)*exp(-x)/sqrt(Pi). 
11758     We use gammainc instead of the usual definition because it is more precise 
11759     for small chi. 
11760     """
11761     return sc.gammainc(1.5, chi**2/2) / 2
11762 
11763 
11764 class argus_gen(rv_continuous):
11765     r""" 
11766     Argus distribution 
11767  
11768     %(before_notes)s 
11769  
11770     Notes 
11771     ----- 
11772     The probability density function for `argus` is: 
11773  
11774     .. math:: 
11775  
11776         f(x, \chi) = \frac{\chi^3}{\sqrt{2\pi} \Psi(\chi)} x \sqrt{1-x^2} 
11777                      \exp(-\chi^2 (1 - x^2)/2) 
11778  
11779     for :math:`0 < x < 1` and :math:`\chi > 0`, where 
11780  
11781     .. math:: 
11782  
11783         \Psi(\chi) = \Phi(\chi) - \chi \phi(\chi) - 1/2 
11784  
11785     with :math:`\Phi` and :math:`\phi` being the CDF and PDF of a standard 
11786     normal distribution, respectively. 
11787  
11788     `argus` takes :math:`\chi` as shape a parameter. Details about sampling 
11789     from the ARGUS distribution can be found in [2]_. 
11790  
11791     %(after_notes)s 
11792  
11793     References 
11794     ---------- 
11795     .. [1] "ARGUS distribution", 
11796            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARGUS_distribution 
11797     .. [2] Christoph Baumgarten "Random variate generation by fast numerical 
11798            inversion in the varying parameter case." Research in Statistics, 
11799            vol. 1, 2023, doi:10.1080/27684520.2023.2279060. 
11800  
11801     .. versionadded:: 0.19.0 
11802  
11803     %(example)s 
11804     """
11805     def _shape_info(self):
11806         return [_ShapeInfo("chi", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
11807 
11808     def _logpdf(self, x, chi):
11809         # for x = 0 or 1, logpdf returns -np.inf
11810         with np.errstate(divide='ignore'):
11811             y = 1.0 - x*x
11812             A = 3*np.log(chi) - _norm_pdf_logC - np.log(_argus_phi(chi))
11813             return A + np.log(x) + 0.5*np.log1p(-x*x) - chi**2 * y / 2
11814 
11815     def _pdf(self, x, chi):
11816         return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, chi))
11817 
11818     def _cdf(self, x, chi):
11819         return 1.0 - self._sf(x, chi)
11820 
11821     def _sf(self, x, chi):
11822         return _argus_phi(chi * np.sqrt((1 - x)*(1 + x))) / _argus_phi(chi)
11823 
11824     def _rvs(self, chi, size=None, random_state=None):
11825         chi = np.asarray(chi)
11826         if chi.size == 1:
11827             out = self._rvs_scalar(chi, numsamples=size,
11828                                    random_state=random_state)
11829         else:
11830             shp, bc = _check_shape(chi.shape, size)
11831             numsamples = int(np.prod(shp))
11832             out = np.empty(size)
11833             it = np.nditer([chi],
11834                            flags=['multi_index'],
11835                            op_flags=[['readonly']])
11836             while not it.finished:
11837                 idx = tuple((it.multi_index[j] if not bc[j] else slice(None))
11838                             for j in range(-len(size), 0))
11839                 r = self._rvs_scalar(it[0], numsamples=numsamples,
11840                                      random_state=random_state)
11841                 out[idx] = r.reshape(shp)
11842                 it.iternext()
11843 
11844         if size == ():
11845             out = out[()]
11846         return out
11847 
11848     def _rvs_scalar(self, chi, numsamples=None, random_state=None):
11849         # if chi <= 1.8:
11850         # use rejection method, see Devroye:
11851         # Non-Uniform Random Variate Generation, 1986, section II.3.2.
11852         # write: PDF f(x) = c * g(x) * h(x), where
11853         # h is [0,1]-valued and g is a density
11854         # we use two ways to write f
11855         #
11856         # Case 1:
11857         # write g(x) = 3*x*sqrt(1-x**2), h(x) = exp(-chi**2 (1-x**2) / 2)
11858         # If X has a distribution with density g its ppf G_inv is given by:
11859         # G_inv(u) = np.sqrt(1 - u**(2/3))
11860         #
11861         # Case 2:
11862         # g(x) = chi**2 * x * exp(-chi**2 * (1-x**2)/2) / (1 - exp(-chi**2 /2))
11863         # h(x) = sqrt(1 - x**2), 0 <= x <= 1
11864         # one can show that
11865         # G_inv(u) = np.sqrt(2*np.log(u*(np.exp(chi**2/2)-1)+1))/chi
11866         #          = np.sqrt(1 + 2*np.log(np.exp(-chi**2/2)*(1-u)+u)/chi**2)
11867         # the latter expression is used for precision with small chi
11868         #
11869         # In both cases, the inverse cdf of g can be written analytically, and
11870         # we can apply the rejection method:
11871         #
11872         # REPEAT
11873         #    Generate U uniformly distributed on [0, 1]
11874         #    Generate X with density g (e.g. via inverse transform sampling:
11875         #    X = G_inv(V) with V uniformly distributed on [0, 1])
11876         # UNTIL X <= h(X)
11877         # RETURN X
11878         #
11879         # We use case 1 for chi <= 0.5 as it maintains precision for small chi
11880         # and case 2 for 0.5 < chi <= 1.8 due to its speed for moderate chi.
11881         #
11882         # if chi > 1.8:
11883         # use relation to the Gamma distribution: if X is ARGUS with parameter
11884         # chi), then Y = chi**2 * (1 - X**2) / 2 has density proportional to
11885         # sqrt(u) * exp(-u) on [0, chi**2 / 2], i.e. a Gamma(3/2) distribution
11886         # conditioned on [0, chi**2 / 2]). Therefore, to sample X from the
11887         # ARGUS distribution, we sample Y from the gamma distribution, keeping
11888         # only samples on [0, chi**2 / 2], and apply the inverse
11889         # transformation X = (1 - 2*Y/chi**2)**(1/2). Since we only
11890         # look at chi > 1.8, gamma(1.5).cdf(chi**2/2) is large enough such
11891         # Y falls in the interval [0, chi**2 / 2] with a high probability:
11892         # stats.gamma(1.5).cdf(1.8**2/2) = 0.644...
11893         #
11894         # The points to switch between the different methods are determined
11895         # by a comparison of the runtime of the different methods. However,
11896         # the runtime is platform-dependent. The implemented values should
11897         # ensure a good overall performance and are supported by an analysis
11898         # of the rejection constants of different methods.
11899 
11900         size1d = tuple(np.atleast_1d(numsamples))
11901         N = int(np.prod(size1d))
11902         x = np.zeros(N)
11903         simulated = 0
11904         chi2 = chi * chi
11905         if chi <= 0.5:
11906             d = -chi2 / 2
11907             while simulated < N:
11908                 k = N - simulated
11909                 u = random_state.uniform(size=k)
11910                 v = random_state.uniform(size=k)
11911                 z = v**(2/3)
11912                 # acceptance condition: u <= h(G_inv(v)). This simplifies to
11913                 accept = (np.log(u) <= d * z)
11914                 num_accept = np.sum(accept)
11915                 if num_accept > 0:
11916                     # we still need to transform z=v**(2/3) to X = G_inv(v)
11917                     rvs = np.sqrt(1 - z[accept])
11918                     x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs
11919                     simulated += num_accept
11920         elif chi <= 1.8:
11921             echi = np.exp(-chi2 / 2)
11922             while simulated < N:
11923                 k = N - simulated
11924                 u = random_state.uniform(size=k)
11925                 v = random_state.uniform(size=k)
11926                 z = 2 * np.log(echi * (1 - v) + v) / chi2
11927                 # as in case one, simplify u <= h(G_inv(v)) and then transform
11928                 # z to the target distribution X = G_inv(v)
11929                 accept = (u**2 + z <= 0)
11930                 num_accept = np.sum(accept)
11931                 if num_accept > 0:
11932                     rvs = np.sqrt(1 + z[accept])
11933                     x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs
11934                     simulated += num_accept
11935         else:
11936             # conditional Gamma for chi > 1.8
11937             while simulated < N:
11938                 k = N - simulated
11939                 g = random_state.standard_gamma(1.5, size=k)
11940                 accept = (g <= chi2 / 2)
11941                 num_accept = np.sum(accept)
11942                 if num_accept > 0:
11943                     x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = g[accept]
11944                     simulated += num_accept
11945             x = np.sqrt(1 - 2 * x / chi2)
11946 
11947         return np.reshape(x, size1d)
11948 
11949     def _stats(self, chi):
11950         # need to ensure that dtype is float
11951         # otherwise the mask below does not work for integers
11952         chi = np.asarray(chi, dtype=float)
11953         phi = _argus_phi(chi)
11954         m = np.sqrt(np.pi/8) * chi * sc.ive(1, chi**2/4) / phi
11955         # compute second moment, use Taylor expansion for small chi (<= 0.1)
11956         mu2 = np.empty_like(chi)
11957         mask = chi > 0.1
11958         c = chi[mask]
11959         mu2[mask] = 1 - 3 / c**2 + c * _norm_pdf(c) / phi[mask]
11960         c = chi[~mask]
11961         coef = [-358/65690625, 0, -94/1010625, 0, 2/2625, 0, 6/175, 0, 0.4]
11962         mu2[~mask] = np.polyval(coef, c)
11963         return m, mu2 - m**2, None, None
11964 
11965 
11966 argus = argus_gen(name='argus', longname="An Argus Function", a=0.0, b=1.0)
11967 
11968 
11969 class rv_histogram(rv_continuous):
11970     """ 
11971     Generates a distribution given by a histogram. 
11972     This is useful to generate a template distribution from a binned 
11973     datasample. 
11974  
11975     As a subclass of the `rv_continuous` class, `rv_histogram` inherits from it 
11976     a collection of generic methods (see `rv_continuous` for the full list), 
11977     and implements them based on the properties of the provided binned 
11978     datasample. 
11979  
11980     Parameters 
11981     ---------- 
11982     histogram : tuple of array_like 
11983         Tuple containing two array_like objects. 
11984         The first containing the content of n bins, 
11985         the second containing the (n+1) bin boundaries. 
11986         In particular, the return value of `numpy.histogram` is accepted. 
11987  
11988     density : bool, optional 
11989         If False, assumes the histogram is proportional to counts per bin; 
11990         otherwise, assumes it is proportional to a density. 
11991         For constant bin widths, these are equivalent, but the distinction 
11992         is important when bin widths vary (see Notes). 
11993         If None (default), sets ``density=True`` for backwards compatibility, 
11994         but warns if the bin widths are variable. Set `density` explicitly 
11995         to silence the warning. 
11996  
11997         .. versionadded:: 1.10.0 
11998  
11999     Notes 
12000     ----- 
12001     When a histogram has unequal bin widths, there is a distinction between 
12002     histograms that are proportional to counts per bin and histograms that are 
12003     proportional to probability density over a bin. If `numpy.histogram` is 
12004     called with its default ``density=False``, the resulting histogram is the 
12005     number of counts per bin, so ``density=False`` should be passed to 
12006     `rv_histogram`. If `numpy.histogram` is called with ``density=True``, the 
12007     resulting histogram is in terms of probability density, so ``density=True`` 
12008     should be passed to `rv_histogram`. To avoid warnings, always pass 
12009     ``density`` explicitly when the input histogram has unequal bin widths. 
12010  
12011     There are no additional shape parameters except for the loc and scale. 
12012     The pdf is defined as a stepwise function from the provided histogram. 
12013     The cdf is a linear interpolation of the pdf. 
12014  
12015     .. versionadded:: 0.19.0 
12016  
12017     Examples 
12018     -------- 
12019  
12020     Create a scipy.stats distribution from a numpy histogram 
12021  
12022     >>> import scipy.stats 
12023     >>> import numpy as np 
12024     >>> data = scipy.stats.norm.rvs(size=100000, loc=0, scale=1.5, 
12025     ...                             random_state=123) 
12026     >>> hist = np.histogram(data, bins=100) 
12027     >>> hist_dist = scipy.stats.rv_histogram(hist, density=False) 
12028  
12029     Behaves like an ordinary scipy rv_continuous distribution 
12030  
12031     >>> hist_dist.pdf(1.0) 
12032     0.20538577847618705 
12033     >>> hist_dist.cdf(2.0) 
12034     0.90818568543056499 
12035  
12036     PDF is zero above (below) the highest (lowest) bin of the histogram, 
12037     defined by the max (min) of the original dataset 
12038  
12039     >>> hist_dist.pdf(np.max(data)) 
12040     0.0 
12041     >>> hist_dist.cdf(np.max(data)) 
12042     1.0 
12043     >>> hist_dist.pdf(np.min(data)) 
12044     7.7591907244498314e-05 
12045     >>> hist_dist.cdf(np.min(data)) 
12046     0.0 
12047  
12048     PDF and CDF follow the histogram 
12049  
12050     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
12051     >>> X = np.linspace(-5.0, 5.0, 100) 
12052     >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots() 
12053     >>> ax.set_title("PDF from Template") 
12054     >>> ax.hist(data, density=True, bins=100) 
12055     >>> ax.plot(X, hist_dist.pdf(X), label='PDF') 
12056     >>> ax.plot(X, hist_dist.cdf(X), label='CDF') 
12057     >>> ax.legend() 
12058     >>> fig.show() 
12059  
12060     """
12061     _support_mask = rv_continuous._support_mask
12062 
12063     def __init__(self, histogram, *args, density=None, **kwargs):
12064         """ 
12065         Create a new distribution using the given histogram 
12066  
12067         Parameters 
12068         ---------- 
12069         histogram : tuple of array_like 
12070             Tuple containing two array_like objects. 
12071             The first containing the content of n bins, 
12072             the second containing the (n+1) bin boundaries. 
12073             In particular, the return value of np.histogram is accepted. 
12074         density : bool, optional 
12075             If False, assumes the histogram is proportional to counts per bin; 
12076             otherwise, assumes it is proportional to a density. 
12077             For constant bin widths, these are equivalent. 
12078             If None (default), sets ``density=True`` for backward 
12079             compatibility, but warns if the bin widths are variable. Set 
12080             `density` explicitly to silence the warning. 
12081         """
12082         self._histogram = histogram
12083         self._density = density
12084         if len(histogram) != 2:
12085             raise ValueError("Expected length 2 for parameter histogram")
12086         self._hpdf = np.asarray(histogram[0])
12087         self._hbins = np.asarray(histogram[1])
12088         if len(self._hpdf) + 1 != len(self._hbins):
12089             raise ValueError("Number of elements in histogram content "
12090                              "and histogram boundaries do not match, "
12091                              "expected n and n+1.")
12092         self._hbin_widths = self._hbins[1:] - self._hbins[:-1]
12093         bins_vary = not np.allclose(self._hbin_widths, self._hbin_widths[0])
12094         if density is None and bins_vary:
12095             message = ("Bin widths are not constant. Assuming `density=True`."
12096                        "Specify `density` explicitly to silence this warning.")
12097             warnings.warn(message, RuntimeWarning, stacklevel=2)
12098             density = True
12099         elif not density:
12100             self._hpdf = self._hpdf / self._hbin_widths
12101 
12102         self._hpdf = self._hpdf / float(np.sum(self._hpdf * self._hbin_widths))
12103         self._hcdf = np.cumsum(self._hpdf * self._hbin_widths)
12104         self._hpdf = np.hstack([0.0, self._hpdf, 0.0])
12105         self._hcdf = np.hstack([0.0, self._hcdf])
12106         # Set support
12107         kwargs['a'] = self.a = self._hbins[0]
12108         kwargs['b'] = self.b = self._hbins[-1]
12109         super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
12110 
12111     def _pdf(self, x):
12112         """ 
12113         PDF of the histogram 
12114         """
12115         return self._hpdf[np.searchsorted(self._hbins, x, side='right')]
12116 
12117     def _cdf(self, x):
12118         """ 
12119         CDF calculated from the histogram 
12120         """
12121         return np.interp(x, self._hbins, self._hcdf)
12122 
12123     def _ppf(self, x):
12124         """ 
12125         Percentile function calculated from the histogram 
12126         """
12127         return np.interp(x, self._hcdf, self._hbins)
12128 
12129     def _munp(self, n):
12130         """Compute the n-th non-central moment."""
12131         integrals = (self._hbins[1:]**(n+1) - self._hbins[:-1]**(n+1)) / (n+1)
12132         return np.sum(self._hpdf[1:-1] * integrals)
12133 
12134     def _entropy(self):
12135         """Compute entropy of distribution"""
12136         res = _lazywhere(self._hpdf[1:-1] > 0.0,
12137                          (self._hpdf[1:-1],),
12138                          np.log,
12139                          0.0)
12140         return -np.sum(self._hpdf[1:-1] * res * self._hbin_widths)
12141 
12142     def _updated_ctor_param(self):
12143         """ 
12144         Set the histogram as additional constructor argument 
12145         """
12146         dct = super()._updated_ctor_param()
12147         dct['histogram'] = self._histogram
12148         dct['density'] = self._density
12149         return dct
12150 
12151 
12152 class studentized_range_gen(rv_continuous):
12153     r"""A studentized range continuous random variable. 
12154  
12155     %(before_notes)s 
12156  
12157     See Also 
12158     -------- 
12159     t: Student's t distribution 
12160  
12161     Notes 
12162     ----- 
12163     The probability density function for `studentized_range` is: 
12164  
12165     .. math:: 
12166  
12167          f(x; k, \nu) = \frac{k(k-1)\nu^{\nu/2}}{\Gamma(\nu/2) 
12168                         2^{\nu/2-1}} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} 
12169                         s^{\nu} e^{-\nu s^2/2} \phi(z) \phi(sx + z) 
12170                         [\Phi(sx + z) - \Phi(z)]^{k-2} \,dz \,ds 
12171  
12172     for :math:`x ≥ 0`, :math:`k > 1`, and :math:`\nu > 0`. 
12173  
12174     `studentized_range` takes ``k`` for :math:`k` and ``df`` for :math:`\nu` 
12175     as shape parameters. 
12176  
12177     When :math:`\nu` exceeds 100,000, an asymptotic approximation (infinite 
12178     degrees of freedom) is used to compute the cumulative distribution 
12179     function [4]_ and probability distribution function. 
12180  
12181     %(after_notes)s 
12182  
12183     References 
12184     ---------- 
12185  
12186     .. [1] "Studentized range distribution", 
12187            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Studentized_range_distribution 
12188     .. [2] Batista, Ben Dêivide, et al. "Externally Studentized Normal Midrange 
12189            Distribution." Ciência e Agrotecnologia, vol. 41, no. 4, 2017, pp. 
12190            378-389., doi:10.1590/1413-70542017414047716. 
12191     .. [3] Harter, H. Leon. "Tables of Range and Studentized Range." The Annals 
12192            of Mathematical Statistics, vol. 31, no. 4, 1960, pp. 1122-1147. 
12193            JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/2237810. Accessed 18 Feb. 2021. 
12194     .. [4] Lund, R. E., and J. R. Lund. "Algorithm AS 190: Probabilities and 
12195            Upper Quantiles for the Studentized Range." Journal of the Royal 
12196            Statistical Society. Series C (Applied Statistics), vol. 32, no. 2, 
12197            1983, pp. 204-210. JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/2347300. Accessed 18 
12198            Feb. 2021. 
12199  
12200     Examples 
12201     -------- 
12202     >>> import numpy as np 
12203     >>> from scipy.stats import studentized_range 
12204     >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
12205     >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) 
12206  
12207     Display the probability density function (``pdf``): 
12208  
12209     >>> k, df = 3, 10 
12210     >>> x = np.linspace(studentized_range.ppf(0.01, k, df), 
12211     ...                 studentized_range.ppf(0.99, k, df), 100) 
12212     >>> ax.plot(x, studentized_range.pdf(x, k, df), 
12213     ...         'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='studentized_range pdf') 
12214  
12215     Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) 
12216     to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a "frozen" 
12217     RV object holding the given parameters fixed. 
12218  
12219     Freeze the distribution and display the frozen ``pdf``: 
12220  
12221     >>> rv = studentized_range(k, df) 
12222     >>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf') 
12223  
12224     Check accuracy of ``cdf`` and ``ppf``: 
12225  
12226     >>> vals = studentized_range.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], k, df) 
12227     >>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], studentized_range.cdf(vals, k, df)) 
12228     True 
12229  
12230     Rather than using (``studentized_range.rvs``) to generate random variates, 
12231     which is very slow for this distribution, we can approximate the inverse 
12232     CDF using an interpolator, and then perform inverse transform sampling 
12233     with this approximate inverse CDF. 
12234  
12235     This distribution has an infinite but thin right tail, so we focus our 
12236     attention on the leftmost 99.9 percent. 
12237  
12238     >>> a, b = studentized_range.ppf([0, .999], k, df) 
12239     >>> a, b 
12240     0, 7.41058083802274 
12241  
12242     >>> from scipy.interpolate import interp1d 
12243     >>> rng = np.random.default_rng() 
12244     >>> xs = np.linspace(a, b, 50) 
12245     >>> cdf = studentized_range.cdf(xs, k, df) 
12246     # Create an interpolant of the inverse CDF 
12247     >>> ppf = interp1d(cdf, xs, fill_value='extrapolate') 
12248     # Perform inverse transform sampling using the interpolant 
12249     >>> r = ppf(rng.uniform(size=1000)) 
12250  
12251     And compare the histogram: 
12252  
12253     >>> ax.hist(r, density=True, histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2) 
12254     >>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False) 
12255     >>> plt.show() 
12256  
12257     """
12258 
12259     def _argcheck(self, k, df):
12260         return (k > 1) & (df > 0)
12261 
12262     def _shape_info(self):
12263         ik = _ShapeInfo("k", False, (1, np.inf), (False, False))
12264         idf = _ShapeInfo("df", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))
12265         return [ik, idf]
12266 
12267     def _fitstart(self, data):
12268         # Default is k=1, but that is not a valid value of the parameter.
12269         return super()._fitstart(data, args=(2, 1))
12270 
12271     def _munp(self, K, k, df):
12272         cython_symbol = '_studentized_range_moment'
12273         _a, _b = self._get_support()
12274         # all three of these are used to create a numpy array so they must
12275         # be the same shape.
12276 
12277         def _single_moment(K, k, df):
12278             log_const = _stats._studentized_range_pdf_logconst(k, df)
12279             arg = [K, k, df, log_const]
12280             usr_data = np.array(arg, float).ctypes.data_as(ctypes.c_void_p)
12281 
12282             llc = LowLevelCallable.from_cython(_stats, cython_symbol, usr_data)
12283 
12284             ranges = [(-np.inf, np.inf), (0, np.inf), (_a, _b)]
12285             opts = dict(epsabs=1e-11, epsrel=1e-12)
12286 
12287             return integrate.nquad(llc, ranges=ranges, opts=opts)[0]
12288 
12289         ufunc = np.frompyfunc(_single_moment, 3, 1)
12290         return np.asarray(ufunc(K, k, df), dtype=np.float64)[()]
12291 
12292     def _pdf(self, x, k, df):
12293 
12294         def _single_pdf(q, k, df):
12295             # The infinite form of the PDF is derived from the infinite
12296             # CDF.
12297             if df < 100000:
12298                 cython_symbol = '_studentized_range_pdf'
12299                 log_const = _stats._studentized_range_pdf_logconst(k, df)
12300                 arg = [q, k, df, log_const]
12301                 usr_data = np.array(arg, float).ctypes.data_as(ctypes.c_void_p)
12302                 ranges = [(-np.inf, np.inf), (0, np.inf)]
12303 
12304             else:
12305                 cython_symbol = '_studentized_range_pdf_asymptotic'
12306                 arg = [q, k]
12307                 usr_data = np.array(arg, float).ctypes.data_as(ctypes.c_void_p)
12308                 ranges = [(-np.inf, np.inf)]
12309 
12310             llc = LowLevelCallable.from_cython(_stats, cython_symbol, usr_data)
12311             opts = dict(epsabs=1e-11, epsrel=1e-12)
12312             return integrate.nquad(llc, ranges=ranges, opts=opts)[0]
12313 
12314         ufunc = np.frompyfunc(_single_pdf, 3, 1)
12315         return np.asarray(ufunc(x, k, df), dtype=np.float64)[()]
12316 
12317     def _cdf(self, x, k, df):
12318 
12319         def _single_cdf(q, k, df):
12320             # "When the degrees of freedom V are infinite the probability
12321             # integral takes [on a] simpler form," and a single asymptotic
12322             # integral is evaluated rather than the standard double integral.
12323             # (Lund, Lund, page 205)
12324             if df < 100000:
12325                 cython_symbol = '_studentized_range_cdf'
12326                 log_const = _stats._studentized_range_cdf_logconst(k, df)
12327                 arg = [q, k, df, log_const]
12328                 usr_data = np.array(arg, float).ctypes.data_as(ctypes.c_void_p)
12329                 ranges = [(-np.inf, np.inf), (0, np.inf)]
12330 
12331             else:
12332                 cython_symbol = '_studentized_range_cdf_asymptotic'
12333                 arg = [q, k]
12334                 usr_data = np.array(arg, float).ctypes.data_as(ctypes.c_void_p)
12335                 ranges = [(-np.inf, np.inf)]
12336 
12337             llc = LowLevelCallable.from_cython(_stats, cython_symbol, usr_data)
12338             opts = dict(epsabs=1e-11, epsrel=1e-12)
12339             return integrate.nquad(llc, ranges=ranges, opts=opts)[0]
12340 
12341         ufunc = np.frompyfunc(_single_cdf, 3, 1)
12342 
12343         # clip p-values to ensure they are in [0, 1].
12344         return np.clip(np.asarray(ufunc(x, k, df), dtype=np.float64)[()], 0, 1)
12345 
12346 
12347 studentized_range = studentized_range_gen(name='studentized_range', a=0,
12348                                           b=np.inf)
12349 
12350 
12351 class rel_breitwigner_gen(rv_continuous):
12352     r"""A relativistic Breit-Wigner random variable. 
12353  
12354     %(before_notes)s 
12355  
12356     See Also 
12357     -------- 
12358     cauchy: Cauchy distribution, also known as the Breit-Wigner distribution. 
12359  
12360     Notes 
12361     ----- 
12362  
12363     The probability density function for `rel_breitwigner` is 
12364  
12365     .. math:: 
12366  
12367         f(x, \rho) = \frac{k}{(x^2 - \rho^2)^2 + \rho^2} 
12368  
12369     where 
12370  
12371     .. math:: 
12372         k = \frac{2\sqrt{2}\rho^2\sqrt{\rho^2 + 1}} 
12373             {\pi\sqrt{\rho^2 + \rho\sqrt{\rho^2 + 1}}} 
12374  
12375     The relativistic Breit-Wigner distribution is used in high energy physics 
12376     to model resonances [1]_. It gives the uncertainty in the invariant mass, 
12377     :math:`M` [2]_, of a resonance with characteristic mass :math:`M_0` and 
12378     decay-width :math:`\Gamma`, where :math:`M`, :math:`M_0` and :math:`\Gamma` 
12379     are expressed in natural units. In SciPy's parametrization, the shape 
12380     parameter :math:`\rho` is equal to :math:`M_0/\Gamma` and takes values in 
12381     :math:`(0, \infty)`. 
12382  
12383     Equivalently, the relativistic Breit-Wigner distribution is said to give 
12384     the uncertainty in the center-of-mass energy :math:`E_{\text{cm}}`. In 
12385     natural units, the speed of light :math:`c` is equal to 1 and the invariant 
12386     mass :math:`M` is equal to the rest energy :math:`Mc^2`. In the 
12387     center-of-mass frame, the rest energy is equal to the total energy [3]_. 
12388  
12389     %(after_notes)s 
12390  
12391     :math:`\rho = M/\Gamma` and :math:`\Gamma` is the scale parameter. For 
12392     example, if one seeks to model the :math:`Z^0` boson with :math:`M_0 
12393     \approx 91.1876 \text{ GeV}` and :math:`\Gamma \approx 2.4952\text{ GeV}` 
12394     [4]_ one can set ``rho=91.1876/2.4952`` and ``scale=2.4952``. 
12395  
12396     To ensure a physically meaningful result when using the `fit` method, one 
12397     should set ``floc=0`` to fix the location parameter to 0. 
12398  
12399     References 
12400     ---------- 
12401     .. [1] Relativistic Breit-Wigner distribution, Wikipedia, 
12402            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relativistic_Breit-Wigner_distribution 
12403     .. [2] Invariant mass, Wikipedia, 
12404            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_mass 
12405     .. [3] Center-of-momentum frame, Wikipedia, 
12406            https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center-of-momentum_frame 
12407     .. [4] M. Tanabashi et al. (Particle Data Group) Phys. Rev. D 98, 030001 - 
12408            Published 17 August 2018 
12409  
12410     %(example)s 
12411  
12412     """
12413     def _argcheck(self, rho):
12414         return rho > 0
12415 
12416     def _shape_info(self):
12417         return [_ShapeInfo("rho", False, (0, np.inf), (False, False))]
12418 
12419     def _pdf(self, x, rho):
12420         # C = k / rho**2
12421         C = np.sqrt(
12422             2 * (1 + 1/rho**2) / (1 + np.sqrt(1 + 1/rho**2))
12423         ) * 2 / np.pi
12424         with np.errstate(over='ignore'):
12425             return C / (((x - rho)*(x + rho)/rho)**2 + 1)
12426 
12427     def _cdf(self, x, rho):
12428         # C = k / (2 * rho**2) / np.sqrt(1 + 1/rho**2)
12429         C = np.sqrt(2/(1 + np.sqrt(1 + 1/rho**2)))/np.pi
12430         result = (
12431             np.sqrt(-1 + 1j/rho)
12432             * np.arctan(x/np.sqrt(-rho*(rho + 1j)))
12433         )
12434         result = C * 2 * np.imag(result)
12435         # Sometimes above formula produces values greater than 1.
12436         return np.clip(result, None, 1)
12437 
12438     def _munp(self, n, rho):
12439         if n == 0:
12440             return 1.
12441         if n == 1:
12442             # C = k / (2 * rho)
12443             C = np.sqrt(
12444                 2 * (1 + 1/rho**2) / (1 + np.sqrt(1 + 1/rho**2))
12445             ) / np.pi * rho
12446             return C * (np.pi/2 + np.arctan(rho))
12447         if n == 2:
12448             # C = pi * k / (4 * rho)
12449             C = np.sqrt(
12450                 (1 + 1/rho**2) / (2 * (1 + np.sqrt(1 + 1/rho**2)))
12451             ) * rho
12452             result = (1 - rho * 1j) / np.sqrt(-1 - 1j/rho)
12453             return 2 * C * np.real(result)
12454         else:
12455             return np.inf
12456 
12457     def _stats(self, rho):
12458         # Returning None from stats makes public stats use _munp.
12459         # nan values will be omitted from public stats. Skew and
12460         # kurtosis are actually infinite.
12461         return None, None, np.nan, np.nan
12462 
12463     @inherit_docstring_from(rv_continuous)
12464     def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds):
12465         # Override rv_continuous.fit to better handle case where floc is set.
12466         data, _, floc, fscale = _check_fit_input_parameters(
12467             self, data, args, kwds
12468         )
12469 
12470         censored = isinstance(data, CensoredData)
12471         if censored:
12472             if data.num_censored() == 0:
12473                 # There are no censored values in data, so replace the
12474                 # CensoredData instance with a regular array.
12475                 data = data._uncensored
12476                 censored = False
12477 
12478         if floc is None or censored:
12479             return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
12480 
12481         if fscale is None:
12482             # The interquartile range approximates the scale parameter gamma.
12483             # The median approximates rho * gamma.
12484             p25, p50, p75 = np.quantile(data - floc, [0.25, 0.5, 0.75])
12485             scale_0 = p75 - p25
12486             rho_0 = p50 / scale_0
12487             if not args:
12488                 args = [rho_0]
12489             if "scale" not in kwds:
12490                 kwds["scale"] = scale_0
12491         else:
12492             M_0 = np.median(data - floc)
12493             rho_0 = M_0 / fscale
12494             if not args:
12495                 args = [rho_0]
12496         return super().fit(data, *args, **kwds)
12497 
12498 
12499 rel_breitwigner = rel_breitwigner_gen(a=0.0, name="rel_breitwigner")
12500 
12501 
12502 # Collect names of classes and objects in this module.
12503 pairs = list(globals().copy().items())
12504 _distn_names, _distn_gen_names = get_distribution_names(pairs, rv_continuous)
12505 
12506 __all__ = _distn_names + _distn_gen_names + ['rv_histogram']
12507
